ai-sn35:53.1.2_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha,
ai-sn35:53.1.3_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:53.2.1_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:53.2.2_0: Knowing and seeing sights, sights, mind consciousness, and mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:53.2.5_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:53.2.10_0: Knowing and seeing the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:53.2.11_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding thoughts ...
ai-sn35:53.2.14_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:53.2.15_0: That’s how to know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”
ai-sn35:53.2.16_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn35:54.1.1_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the fetters are given up?”
ai-sn35:54.1.2_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye as impermanent, the fetters are given up ...”
ai-sn35:54.1.6_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as impermanent, the fetters are given up.
ai-sn35:54.1.12_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding thoughts ...
ai-sn35:54.1.15_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as impermanent, the fetters are given up.
ai-sn35:54.1.16_0: This is how to know and see so that the fetters are given up.”
ai-sn35:55.1.1_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the fetters are uprooted?”
ai-sn35:55.1.2_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye as not-self, the fetters are uprooted ...”
ai-sn35:55.1.6_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as not-self, the fetters are uprooted.
ai-sn35:55.1.12_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding thoughts ...
ai-sn35:55.1.15_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as not-self, the fetters are uprooted.
ai-sn35:55.1.16_0: That’s how to know and see so that the fetters are uprooted.”
ai-sn35:56.1.1_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the defilements are given up?” ...
ai-sn35:57.1.1_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the defilements are uprooted?” ...
ai-sn35:58.1.1_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the underlying tendencies are given up?” ...
ai-sn35:59.1.1_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that the underlying tendencies are uprooted?” ...
ai-sn35:59.1.2_0: I’ll go to the underlying tendencies?”
ai-sn35:59.1.3_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as not-self ...
ai-sn35:59.1.9_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding thoughts ...
ai-sn35:59.1.12_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as not-self, the underlying tendencies are uprooted.
ai-sn35:59.1.13_0: That’s how to know and see so that the underlying tendencies are uprooted.”
ai-sn35:60.0.3_0: 60. The Complete Understanding of All Grasping
ai-sn35:60.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle for the complete understanding of all grasping.
ai-sn35:60.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:60.1.3_0: And what is the principle for the complete understanding of all grasping?
ai-sn35:60.1.4_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:60.1.5_0: Contact is a condition for feeling.
ai-sn35:60.1.6_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and feeling.
ai-sn35:60.1.7_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are released, they understand: ‘I have completely depleted grasping.’
ai-sn35:60.1.8_0: Ear consciousness arises dependent on the ear and sounds. ...
ai-sn35:60.1.12_0: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:60.1.13_0: Contact is a condition for feeling.
ai-sn35:60.1.14_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, mind contact, and feeling.
ai-sn35:60.1.15_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are released, they understand: ‘I have completely depleted grasping.’
ai-sn35:60.1.16_0: This is the principle for the complete understanding of all grasping.”
ai-sn35:61.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle free of grasping.
ai-sn35:61.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:61.1.3_0: And what is the principle that depends on the grasping?
ai-sn35:61.1.4_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:61.1.5_0: Contact is a condition for feeling.
ai-sn35:61.1.6_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, eye contact, and feeling.
ai-sn35:61.1.7_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are released, they understand: ‘I have completely depleted grasping.’
ai-sn35:61.1.9_0: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:61.1.10_0: Contact is a condition for feeling.
ai-sn35:61.1.11_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, mind contact, and feeling.
ai-sn35:61.1.12_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they are released, they understand: ‘I have completely depleted grasping.’
ai-sn35:61.1.13_0: This is the principle to grasp without grasping.”
ai-sn35:62.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the principle free of grasping.
ai-sn35:62.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:62.1.3_0: And what is the principle that depends on the grasping?
ai-sn35:62.2.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:62.4.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:62.6.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:62.6.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:62.12.1_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:62.14.9_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:62.16.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:62.18.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:62.18.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:62.20.1_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact.
ai-sn35:62.20.2_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact.
ai-sn35:62.20.3_0: They grow disillusioned with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:62.20.4_0: They are repelled by the mind, repelled by mental phenomena, repelled by mind-consciousness, repelled by mind-contact, and repelled by whatever feelings arise because of mind.
ai-sn35:62.20.5_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:62.20.6_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:62.20.7_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-sn35:62.20.8_0: This is the principle to grasp without grasping.”
ai-sn35:62.20.10_0: The first sub-chapter on ignorance is finished.
ai-sn35:62.21.1_0: ignorance, two fetters are given up:
ai-sn35:62.21.2_0: two defilements have been spoken of,
ai-sn35:63.1.2_0: Then Venerable Migajāla went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:63.1.3_0: Then he said to the Buddha,
ai-sn35:63.1.4_0: “Sir, they speak of one who lives alone.
ai-sn35:63.1.5_0: How do you live alone, withdrawn in body and mind?”
ai-sn35:63.2.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:63.2.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:63.2.5_0: and there is core of substance.
ai-sn35:63.2.6_0: A mendicant who is fettered by relishing is said to live alone.
ai-sn35:63.2.8_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:63.2.9_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:63.2.12_0: and there is core of substance.
ai-sn35:63.2.13_0: A mendicant who is fettered by relishing is said to live alone.
ai-sn35:63.2.14_0: A mendicant who lives like this is said to live alone, far from the wilderness, frequenting remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest that are quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat.
ai-sn35:63.2.15_0: the student was said to live with.
ai-sn35:63.2.17_0: For craving is their partner, and they haven’t given it up.
ai-sn35:63.2.18_0: That’s why they’re said to live with a partner.
ai-sn35:63.3.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:63.3.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:63.3.3_0: As a result, relishing of relishing and greed ceases.
ai-sn35:63.3.4_0: When there’s no relishing there’s no greed.
ai-sn35:63.3.5_0: When there are no essentials, there is no attachment.
ai-sn35:63.3.6_0: A mendicant who is not fettered by relishing is said to live alone.
ai-sn35:63.3.7_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:63.3.8_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:63.3.9_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:63.3.10_0: As a result, relishing of relishing and greed ceases.
ai-sn35:63.3.11_0: When there’s no relishing there’s no greed.
ai-sn35:63.3.12_0: When there are no essentials, there is no attachment.
ai-sn35:63.3.13_0: A mendicant who is not fettered by relishing is said to live alone.
ai-sn35:63.3.14_0: A mendicant who lives like this is said to live alone, even if they live in the neighborhood of a village crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their ministers, and teachers of other paths and their disciples.
ai-sn35:63.3.15_0: A alone is what is meant.
ai-sn35:63.3.17_0: For craving is their partner, and they have given it up.
ai-sn35:63.3.18_0: That’s why they’re said to live alone.”
ai-sn35:63.3.19_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn35:64.1.1_0: Then Venerable Migajāla went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:64.1.2_0: Then he said to the Buddha,
ai-sn35:64.1.3_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:64.2.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:64.2.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:64.2.4_0: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
ai-sn35:64.2.5_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:64.2.6_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:64.2.7_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:64.2.9_0: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
ai-sn35:64.3.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:64.3.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:64.3.2_1: As a result, relishing of relishing and greed ceases.
ai-sn35:64.3.3_0: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.
ai-sn35:64.3.4_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:64.3.5_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:64.3.6_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:64.3.6_1: As a result, relishing of relishing and greed ceases.
ai-sn35:64.3.7_0: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.”
ai-sn35:64.4.1_0: And then Venerable Migajāla approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-sn35:64.4.2_0: Then Migajāla, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-sn35:64.4.3_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-sn35:64.4.4_0: And Venerable Migajāla became one of the perfected.
ai-sn35:65.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn35:65.1.2_0: Then Venerable Samiddhi went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:65.1.5_0: How do we define Māra or what is known as Māra?”
ai-sn35:65.2.1_0: “Samiddhi, where there is the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and phenomena to be known by eye consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.2.2_0: Where there is the ear, sounds, ear consciousness, and phenomena to be known by ear consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.2.3_0: Where there is the nose, smells, nose consciousness, and phenomena to be known by nose consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.2.4_0: Where there is the tongue, tastes, tongue consciousness, and phenomena to be known by tongue consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.2.5_0: Where there is the body, touches, body consciousness, and phenomena to be known by body consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.2.6_0: Where there is the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and phenomena to be known by mind consciousness, there is Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.3.1_0: Where there is no eye, no sights, no eye consciousness, and no phenomena to be known by eye consciousness, there is no Māra or what is known as Māra.
ai-sn35:65.3.6_0: Where there is no mind, no thoughts, no mind consciousness, and no phenomena to be known by mind consciousness, there is no Māra or what is known as Māra.”
ai-sn35:66.0.3_0: 66. Samiddhi’s Question About a Sentient Being
ai-sn35:66.1.1_0: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘the sentient being’.
ai-sn35:66.1.2_0: How do we define a sentient being or what is known as a sentient being?” ...
ai-sn35:67.1.1_0: “Sir, they speak of this thing called ‘suffering’.
ai-sn35:67.1.2_0: How do we define suffering or what is known as suffering?” ...
ai-sn35:68.1.2_0: How do we define the world or what is known as the world?”
ai-sn35:68.1.3_0: “Samiddhi, where there is the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and phenomena to be known by eye consciousness, there is the world or what is known as the world.
ai-sn35:68.1.4_0: Where there is the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:68.1.5_0: Where there is the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and phenomena to be known by mind consciousness, there is the world or what is known as the world.
ai-sn35:68.2.1_0: Where there is no eye, no sights, no eye consciousness, and no phenomena to be known by eye consciousness, there is no world or what is known as the world.
ai-sn35:68.2.2_0: Where there is no ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:68.2.3_0: Where there is no mind, no thoughts, no mind consciousness, and no phenomena to be known by mind consciousness, there is no world or what is known as the world.”
ai-sn35:69.1.1_0: At one time the venerables Sāriputta and Upasena were staying near Rājagaha in the Cool Wood, under the Snake’s Hood Grotto.
ai-sn35:69.1.2_0: Now at that time a viper fell on Upasena’s body,
ai-sn35:69.1.4_0: “Come, reverends, lift this body onto a cot and carry it outside
ai-sn35:69.2.1_0: When he said this, Sāriputta said to him,
ai-sn35:69.2.2_0: “But we don’t see any impairment in your body or deterioration of your faculties.
ai-sn35:69.2.4_0: ‘Come, reverends, lift this body onto a cot and carry it outside
ai-sn35:69.2.7_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, there may be an impairment in body or deterioration of faculties for someone who thinks:
ai-sn35:69.2.8_0: ‘I am the eye’ or ‘the eye is mine.’
ai-sn35:69.2.9_0: Or ‘I am the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...’
ai-sn35:69.2.10_0: Or ‘I am the mind’ or ‘the mind is mine.’
ai-sn35:69.2.11_0: As I might change and fall apart.
ai-sn35:69.2.12_0: But I don’t think like that.
ai-sn35:69.2.13_0: ‘I am the eye’ or ‘the eye is mine.’
ai-sn35:69.2.15_0: Or ‘I am the mind’ or ‘the mind is mine.’
ai-sn35:69.2.16_0: So why would there be an impairment in my body or deterioration of my faculties?”
ai-sn35:69.3.1_0: “That must be because Venerable Upasena has long ago totally eradicated ego, possessiveness, and the underlying tendency to conceit.
ai-sn35:69.3.2_0: That’s why it doesn’t occur to you:
ai-sn35:69.3.3_0: ‘I am the eye’ or ‘the eye is mine.’ Or ‘I am the ear ...
ai-sn35:69.3.5_0: Or ‘I am the mind’ or ‘the mind is mine.’”
ai-sn35:69.3.6_0: Then those mendicants lifted Upasena’s body onto a cot and carried it outside.
ai-sn35:69.3.7_0: And his body was scattered right there
ai-sn35:70.0.3_0: 70. Upavāṇa on What is Visible in This Very Life
ai-sn35:70.1.1_0: Then Venerable Upavāṇa went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:70.1.3_0: “Sir, they speak of ‘a teaching visible in this very life’.
ai-sn35:70.1.4_0: In what way is the teaching visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves?”
ai-sn35:70.2.1_0: “Upavāṇa, take a mendicant who sees a sight with their eyes. They experience both the sight and the desire for the sight.
ai-sn35:70.2.2_0: There is desire for sights in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.2.4_0: There is desire for sights in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.2.5_0: this is how the teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
ai-sn35:70.3.1_0: Next, take a mendicant who hears ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:70.3.2_0: There is desire for greed, relishing, and craving for tastes.
ai-sn35:70.3.4_0: There is desire for greed, relishing, and craving for tastes.
ai-sn35:70.3.4_1: this is how the teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
ai-sn35:70.4.1_0: Next, take a mendicant who knows a thought with their mind. They experience both the thought and the desire for the thought.
ai-sn35:70.4.2_0: There is desire for thoughts in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.4.4_0: There is desire for thoughts in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.4.5_0: this is how the teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
ai-sn35:70.5.1_0: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with their eyes. They experience the sight but no desire for the sight.
ai-sn35:70.5.2_0: There is no desire for sights in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.5.4_0: There is no desire for sights in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.5.5_0: this is how the teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
ai-sn35:70.6.1_0: Next, take a mendicant who hears ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:70.6.1_1: There is no desire for sounds ...
ai-sn35:70.7.1_0: Next, take a mendicant who knows a thought with their mind. They experience the thought but no desire for the thought.
ai-sn35:70.7.2_0: There is no desire for thoughts in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.7.3_0: Next, take a mendicant who knows a thought with their mind. They experience the thought but no desire for the thought.
ai-sn35:70.7.4_0: There is no desire for thoughts in them, and they understand that.
ai-sn35:70.7.5_0: this is how the teaching is visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.”
ai-sn35:71.1.1_0: “Mendicants, any mendicant who doesn’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape,
ai-sn35:71.1.2_0: He is surrounded by this spiritual life.”
ai-sn35:71.2.1_0: When this was said, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-sn35:71.2.3_0: For I do not truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.”
ai-sn35:71.3.2_0: Do you regard the eye like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:71.5.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the eye, you will truly see clearly with right wisdom that: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn35:71.5.2_0: Just this is the end of suffering.
ai-sn35:71.5.3_0: Do you regard the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:71.7.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:71.7.2_0: Just this is the end of suffering.
ai-sn35:71.7.3_0: Do you regard the mind like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:71.9.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the mind that is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.”
ai-sn35:72.1.1_0: “Mendicants, any mendicant who doesn’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape,
ai-sn35:72.1.2_0: He is surrounded by this spiritual life.”
ai-sn35:72.2.1_0: When this was said, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-sn35:72.2.3_0: For I do not truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.”
ai-sn35:72.3.2_0: Do you regard the eye like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”
ai-sn35:72.5.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the eye, you will truly see clearly with right wisdom that: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn35:72.5.2_0: In this way you will give up the first field of contact, so that there are no more future lives.
ai-sn35:72.6.1_0: Do you regard the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:72.8.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:72.8.1_1: In this way you will give up the fourth field of contact, so that there are no more future lives.
ai-sn35:72.9.1_0: Do you regard the mind like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”
ai-sn35:72.11.1_0: “Good, mendicant! And regarding the mind that is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.”
ai-sn35:72.11.2_0: In this way you will give up the sixth field of contact, so that there are no more future lives.”
ai-sn35:73.1.1_0: “Mendicants, any mendicant who doesn’t truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape,
ai-sn35:73.1.2_0: He is surrounded by this spiritual life.”
ai-sn35:73.2.1_0: When this was said, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-sn35:73.2.3_0: For I do not truly understand the six fields of contacts’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.”
ai-sn35:73.3.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:73.5.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:73.7.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:73.7.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:73.9.5_0: Is the mind permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:73.11.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:73.13.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:73.13.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:73.15.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn35:73.15.2_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:73.15.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:73.15.5_0: The second sub-chapter on deer is finished.
ai-sn35:73.16.1_0: The two friends are spoken of,
ai-sn35:74.1.2_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and said:
ai-sn35:74.1.3_0: “Sir, in a certain dwelling, there’s no other mendicant who is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
ai-sn35:74.1.4_0: “Sir, please go to that mendicant out of compassion.”
ai-sn35:74.2.1_0: Knowing his words, the Buddha gave nine orifices, thinking, “Monk, this mendicant goes to the monks.”
ai-sn35:74.2.2_0: That monk saw the Buddha coming off in the distance.
ai-sn35:74.2.4_0: The Buddha said to that monk,
ai-sn35:74.2.5_0: “It’s all right, monk, don’t get up.
ai-sn35:74.2.6_0: There are some seats spread out by others, I will sit there.”
ai-sn35:74.2.7_0: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out
ai-sn35:74.2.9_0: “Mendicant, I hope you’re keeping well; I hope you’re alright. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
ai-sn35:74.3.1_0: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.”
ai-sn35:74.4.1_0: “I hope you don’t have any remorse or regret?”
ai-sn35:74.5.1_0: “Indeed, sir, I have no little remorse and regret.”
ai-sn35:74.6.1_0: “I hope you have no reason to blame yourself when it comes to ethical conduct?”
ai-sn35:74.7.1_0: “Sir, I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”
ai-sn35:74.8.1_0: “In that case, mendicant, why do you have remorse and regret?”
ai-sn35:74.9.1_0: “I don’t understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete ending of ethics.”
ai-sn35:74.10.1_0: “In that case, mendicant, why did you understand the teaching of my ethics? What, have you taught?”
ai-sn35:74.11.1_0: “I understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of the fading away of greed.”
ai-sn35:74.12.2_0: It’s good that you understand that I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of the fading away of greed.
ai-sn35:74.12.3_0: For that is indeed the purpose.
ai-sn35:74.12.5_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:74.14.6_0: Is the mind permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:74.16.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:74.18.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:74.18.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:74.20.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn35:74.20.1_1: They are repelled by the mind, repelled by that.
ai-sn35:74.20.2_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:74.20.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended ... there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:74.21.1_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:74.21.2_0: Satisfied, that mendicant was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:74.21.3_0: And while this discourse was being spoken, the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in that mendicant:
ai-sn35:74.21.4_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
ai-sn35:74.21.5_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn35:75.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and asked him,
ai-sn35:75.1.2_0: “Sir, in a certain dwelling, there’s no other mendicant who is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
ai-sn35:75.1.3_0: “Sir, please go to that mendicant out of compassion.”
ai-sn35:75.2.1_0: Knowing his words, the Buddha gave nine orifices, thinking, “Monk, this mendicant goes to the monks.”
ai-sn35:75.2.2_0: That monk saw the Buddha coming off in the distance.
ai-sn35:75.2.4_0: The Buddha said to that monk,
ai-sn35:75.2.5_0: “It’s all right, monk, don’t get up.
ai-sn35:75.2.6_0: There are some seats spread out by others, I will sit there.”
ai-sn35:75.2.7_0: He sat on the seat spread out and said to the mendicant,
ai-sn35:75.2.8_0: “Mendicant, I hope you’re keeping well; I hope you’re alright. And I hope the pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
ai-sn35:75.3.1_0: “Sir, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. ...
ai-sn35:75.3.2_0: I have no reason to blame myself when it comes to ethical conduct.”
ai-sn35:75.4.1_0: “In that case, mendicant, why do you have remorse and regret?”
ai-sn35:75.5.1_0: “I don’t understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete ending of ethics.”
ai-sn35:75.6.1_0: “In that case, mendicant, why did you understand the teaching of my ethics? What, have you taught?”
ai-sn35:75.7.1_0: “I understand that the Buddha has taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete extinguishment by not grasping.”
ai-sn35:75.8.2_0: It’s good that you understand that I’ve taught the Dhamma for the purpose of complete extinguishment by not grasping.
ai-sn35:75.8.3_0: For that is indeed the purpose.
ai-sn35:75.9.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:75.11.9_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:75.13.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:75.15.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:75.15.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:75.17.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye ... ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:75.17.5_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:75.17.6_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:75.17.7_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:75.18.1_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:75.18.2_0: Satisfied, that mendicant was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:75.18.3_0: And while this discourse was being spoken, the mind of that mendicant was freed from defilements by not grasping.
ai-sn35:76.1.1_0: The Venerable Rādha went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:76.1.3_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:76.1.4_0: “Rādha, you should give up desire for what is impermanent.
ai-sn35:76.1.8_0: And the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:76.1.8_1: You should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:76.1.11_0: you should give up desire for them.
ai-sn35:76.1.15_0: The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:76.1.15_1: You should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:76.1.16_0: You should give up desire for what is impermanent.”
ai-sn35:77.1.1_0: “Rādha, you should give up desire for what is suffering. ...”
ai-sn35:77.1.3_0: The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are suffering.
ai-sn35:77.1.7_0: The eye contact is also suffering; you should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:77.1.12_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also suffering.
ai-sn35:77.1.12_1: You should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:77.1.13_0: You should give up desire for what is suffering.”
ai-sn35:78.1.1_0: “Rādha, you should give up desire for what is not-self. ...”
ai-sn35:78.1.3_0: The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are not-self.
ai-sn35:78.1.7_0: And the eye contact is a condition for eye contact. ...
ai-sn35:78.1.12_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also not-self.
ai-sn35:78.1.12_1: You should give up desire for it.
ai-sn35:78.1.13_0: You should give up desire for what is not-self.”
ai-sn35:79.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and said:
ai-sn35:79.1.3_0: “Sir, is there one thing that gives up ignorance, and gives rise to knowledge, and gives rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:79.4.1_0: “Mendicant, one thing, who gives up ignorance, and gives rise to knowledge, and gives rise to knowledge.”
ai-sn35:79.5.1_0: “But how does a mendicant know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:79.6.1_0: “When a mendicant knows and sees the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:79.6.2_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises. ...
ai-sn35:79.6.3_0: Knowing and seeing the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:79.6.4_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as impermanent, ignorance is given up and knowledge arises.
ai-sn35:79.6.5_0: That’s how to know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”
ai-sn35:80.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and asked him,
ai-sn35:80.1.2_0: “Sir, is there one thing that gives up ignorance, and gives rise to knowledge, and gives rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:80.4.1_0: “Mendicant, one thing, who gives up ignorance, and gives rise to knowledge, and gives rise to knowledge.”
ai-sn35:80.5.1_0: “But how does a mendicant know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge?”
ai-sn35:80.6.3_0: When a mendicant has heard that
ai-sn35:80.6.5_0: they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Completely understanding all things, they see all signs as other. They see the eye, sights,
ai-sn35:80.6.8_0: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as other. ...
ai-sn35:80.6.12_0: And they also see the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as other.
ai-sn35:80.6.13_0: That’s how to know and see so as to give up ignorance and give rise to knowledge.”
ai-sn35:81.1.1_0: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:81.1.3_0: ‘Reverend, what’s the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the ascetic Gotama?’
ai-sn35:81.1.4_0: When they said this, we would answer them:
ai-sn35:81.1.5_0: ‘The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand suffering.’
ai-sn35:81.1.6_0: We trust that those who say this repeat what the Buddha has said, and do not misrepresent him with an untruth? Is their explanation in line with the teaching? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuke and criticism?”
ai-sn35:81.2.1_0: “Indeed, monks, in answering this way you repeat what I’ve said, and don’t misrepresent me with an untruth. Your explanation is in line with the teaching, and there are no legitimate grounds for rebuke or criticism.
ai-sn35:81.2.2_0: For the purpose of leading the spiritual life under me is to completely understand suffering.
ai-sn35:81.2.3_0: If wanderers who follow other paths were to ask you:
ai-sn35:81.2.5_0: When questioned by wanderers who follow other paths, that’s how you should answer them:
ai-sn35:81.2.6_0: ‘Reverends, the eye is suffering. The purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:81.2.8_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also suffering.
ai-sn35:81.2.9_0: The purpose of living the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:81.2.11_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also suffering.
ai-sn35:81.2.12_0: The purpose of living the spiritual life under the Buddha is to completely understand this.
ai-sn35:81.2.13_0: This is the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha.’
ai-sn35:81.2.14_0: When questioned by wanderers who follow other paths, that’s how you should answer them.”
ai-sn35:82.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and said to him:
ai-sn35:82.2.3_0: “It wears away, mendicant, that’s why it’s called ‘the world’.
ai-sn35:82.2.6_0: Sights ... eye consciousness ... eye contact is wearing away. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also wearing away.
ai-sn35:82.2.8_0: The mind ... thoughts ... mind consciousness ... mind contact is wearing away. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also wearing away.
ai-sn35:82.2.9_0: It wears away, mendicant, that’s why it’s called ‘the world’.”
ai-sn35:83.2.1_0: “Sir, suppose someone were to describe the Buddhas of the past who have become completely extinguished, cut off proliferation, cut off the track, finished off the cycle, and transcended suffering. Does the eye exist by which they could be described?
ai-sn35:83.2.2_0: Does the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body exist ...?
ai-sn35:83.2.3_0: Does the mind exist by which they could be described?”
ai-sn35:83.3.1_0: “Phagguna, suppose someone were to describe the Buddhas of the past who have become completely extinguished, cut off proliferation, cut off the track, finished off the cycle, and transcended suffering. The eye does not exist by which they could be described.
ai-sn35:83.3.2_0: The ear ... nose ... tongue ... body does not exist ...
ai-sn35:83.3.3_0: The mind does not exist by which they could be described.”
ai-sn35:83.3.5_0: The third sub-chapter on sick is finished.
ai-sn35:84.1.2_0: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha ... and asked him,
ai-sn35:84.2.3_0: “Ānanda, that which wears out is called the world in the training of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:84.2.5_0: The eye wears out. Sights ... eye consciousness ... eye contact wears out. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact also wears out.
ai-sn35:84.2.7_0: The mind ... thoughts ... mind consciousness ... mind contact wears out. The painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact also wears out.
ai-sn35:84.2.8_0: That which wears out is called the world in the training of the Noble One.”
ai-sn35:84.2.9_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn35:85.1.1_0: And then Venerable Ānanda ... said to the Buddha:
ai-sn35:85.1.2_0: “Sir, they say that ‘the world is empty’.
ai-sn35:85.1.3_0: What does the saying ‘the world is empty’ refer to?”
ai-sn35:85.1.4_0: “Ānanda, they say that ‘the world is empty’ because it’s empty of self or what belongs to self.
ai-sn35:85.1.5_0: And what is empty of self or what belongs to self?
ai-sn35:85.1.6_0: It’s empty of the eye or what self.
ai-sn35:85.1.7_0: sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are empty of self or what belongs to self. ...
ai-sn35:85.1.8_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also empty of self or what belongs to self.
ai-sn35:85.1.9_0: They say that ‘the world is empty’ because it’s empty of self or what belongs to self.”
ai-sn35:86.1.2_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:86.2.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:86.4.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:86.6.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:86.6.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:86.8.1_0: “What do you think: are sights permanent or impermanent?”—
ai-sn35:86.10.2_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:86.12.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:86.14.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:86.14.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:86.16.1_0: “Is the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ... mind ...
ai-sn35:86.18.3_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:86.20.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:86.22.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:86.22.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:86.24.1_0: “Seeing this, Ānanda, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye ... ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:86.24.2_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:86.24.3_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:86.24.4_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:87.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn35:87.1.2_0: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahācunda were staying on the Vulture Peak Mountain.
ai-sn35:87.1.3_0: Now at that time Venerable Channa was sick, suffering, gravely ill.
ai-sn35:87.1.4_0: Then in the late afternoon, Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahācunda,
ai-sn35:87.1.5_0: “Come, let’s go to Venerable Channa and ask him about his sick.”
ai-sn35:87.2.1_0: And then Sāriputta and Mahācunda went to see Channa and
ai-sn35:87.2.1_1: sat down on the seat spread out,
ai-sn35:87.2.2_0: “I hope you’re keeping well, Reverend Channa; I hope you’re alright. I hope that your pain is fading, not growing, that its fading is evident, not its growing.”
ai-sn35:87.3.1_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.
ai-sn35:87.3.2_0: like a strong man was drilling into my head with a sharp point.
ai-sn35:87.3.2_1: In the same way, strong winds ground my head.
ai-sn35:87.3.3_0: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. ...
ai-sn35:87.3.4_0: like a strong man was tightening a tough leather strap around my head.
ai-sn35:87.3.4_1: In the same way, the headache of the eye ...
ai-sn35:87.3.5_0: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. ...
ai-sn35:87.3.6_0: like a deft butcher or their apprentice was slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver.
ai-sn35:87.3.6_1: In the same way, when cutting off a belly is cut off,
ai-sn35:87.3.7_0: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. ...
ai-sn35:87.3.8_0: Suppose there were two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.
ai-sn35:87.3.8_1: In the same way, there are burning in the body.
ai-sn35:87.3.9_0: I’m not keeping well, I’m not alright. The pain is terrible and growing, not fading; its growing is evident, not its fading.
ai-sn35:87.4.2_0: Venerable Channa, keep going! We want you to keep going.
ai-sn35:87.4.3_0: Suppose I didn’t have suitable food,
ai-sn35:87.4.4_0: There’s no suitable medicine, I’ll look for medicine.
ai-sn35:87.4.5_0: If he doesn’t have a capable carer, I’ll nurse him.
ai-sn35:87.4.7_0: Venerable Channa, keep going! We want you to keep going.”
ai-sn35:87.5.1_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s not that I don’t have suitable food;
ai-sn35:87.5.6_0: I do have a capable carer.
ai-sn35:87.5.7_0: Moreover, for a long time now I have served the Teacher with love, not without love.
ai-sn35:87.5.8_0: For it is proper for a disciple to serve the Teacher with love, not without love.
ai-sn35:87.5.9_0: You should remember this: ‘The mendicant Channa slit his wrists blamelessly.’”
ai-sn35:87.6.1_0: “I’d like to ask you about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
ai-sn35:87.6.2_0: “Ask, Reverend Sāriputta. When I’ve heard it I’ll know.”
ai-sn35:87.7.1_0: “Reverend Channa, do you regard the eye, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness in this way: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?
ai-sn35:87.7.2_0: Do you regard the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:87.7.3_0: mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness in this way: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:87.8.1_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, I regard the eye, eye consciousness, and things knowable by eye consciousness in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
ai-sn35:87.8.3_0: mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness.
ai-sn35:87.9.1_0: “Reverend Channa, what have you seen, what have you directly known in these things that you regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”
ai-sn35:87.9.2_0: Do you regard the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:87.9.3_0: mind, what have you seen, what have you directly known in these things that you regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’?”
ai-sn35:87.10.1_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, after seeing cessation, after directly knowing cessation in these things I regard them in this way: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self’.”
ai-sn35:87.10.2_0: after seeing cessation, Sāriputta, I regard the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:87.10.3_0: mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and things knowable by mind consciousness.
ai-sn35:87.11.1_0: When he said this, Venerable Mahācunda said to Venerable Channa:
ai-sn35:87.11.2_0: “So, Reverend Channa, you should pay close attention to this instruction of the Buddha whenever you can:
ai-sn35:87.11.3_0: ‘For the dependent there is agitation. For the independent there’s no agitation.
ai-sn35:87.11.4_0: When there’s no agitation there is tranquility.
ai-sn35:87.11.5_0: When there’s tranquility there’s no inclination.
ai-sn35:87.11.6_0: When there’s no inclination there’s no coming and going.
ai-sn35:87.11.7_0: When there’s no coming and going there’s no passing away and reappearing.
ai-sn35:87.11.8_0: When there’s no passing away and reappearing, there’s no this world or world beyond or between the two.
ai-sn35:87.11.9_0: This is the end of suffering.’”
ai-sn35:87.12.1_0: And then Sāriputta got up from his seat and left because of this advice.
ai-sn35:87.12.2_0: Not long after those venerables had left, Venerable Channa slit his wrists.
ai-sn35:87.13.1_0: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha,
ai-sn35:87.13.3_0: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”
ai-sn35:87.13.4_0: “Didn’t you ever declare such a mendicant in the presence of Sāriputta?”
ai-sn35:87.13.5_0: “Sir, there is a Vajjian village named Pubbavijjhana
ai-sn35:87.13.6_0: You have all been corrected by Channa in a family of families.”
ai-sn35:87.13.7_0: “The mendicant Channa did indeed have such families, Sāriputta.
ai-sn35:87.13.8_0: But this is not enough for me to call someone ‘blameworthy’.
ai-sn35:87.13.9_0: When someone lays down this body and takes up another body, I call them ‘blameworthy’.
ai-sn35:87.13.10_0: You don’t have the six sense fields.
ai-sn35:87.13.11_0: You should remember this: ‘The mendicant Channa slit his wrists blamelessly.’”
ai-sn35:87.13.12_0: That’s how you should remember it.”
ai-sn35:88.1.1_0: And then Venerable Puṇṇa went up to the Buddha,
ai-sn35:88.1.1_1: a monk goes and is asking ...
ai-sn35:88.1.1_2: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha,
ai-sn35:88.1.2_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:88.2.1_0: (This should be told in full as in SN 35.18.)
ai-sn35:88.2.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:88.2.4_0: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
ai-sn35:88.2.5_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:88.2.6_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:88.2.7_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:88.2.9_0: Relishing is the origin of suffering, I say.
ai-sn35:88.3.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:88.3.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, their rely on that and ceases.
ai-sn35:88.3.3_0: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say. ...
ai-sn35:88.3.4_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:88.3.5_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, their rely on that and ceases.
ai-sn35:88.3.6_0: When relishing ceases, suffering ceases, I say.
ai-sn35:88.4.1_0: Puṇṇa, now that I’ve given you this brief advice, what country will you live in?”
ai-sn35:88.4.2_0: “Sir, there’s a country called Sunāparanta; I will live there.”
ai-sn35:88.5.2_0: Harsh speech is nice and pleasant.
ai-sn35:88.5.3_0: If they abuse and insult you, what will you think of them?”
ai-sn35:88.6.1_0: “If they abuse and insult me, I will think:
ai-sn35:88.6.2_0: ‘This must be because of those humans!’
ai-sn35:88.6.3_0: That is how it should be.
ai-sn35:88.6.4_0: This is how it will be.”
ai-sn35:88.7.1_0: “But if they do hit you with their fists, what will you think of them then?”
ai-sn35:88.8.1_0: “If they hit me with their fists, I’ll think:
ai-sn35:88.8.2_0: ‘This must be because of the heavenly hosts of humans, while these people are absorbed in hell.’
ai-sn35:88.8.3_0: That is how it should be.
ai-sn35:88.8.4_0: This is how it will be.”
ai-sn35:88.9.1_0: “But if they do throw stones at you, what will you think of them then?”
ai-sn35:88.10.1_0: “If they throw stones at me, I’ll think:
ai-sn35:88.10.2_0: ‘This is truly beautiful for these ordinary people with arms, when they’re beatens and throats, what they don’t lead someone with a staff.’
ai-sn35:88.10.3_0: That is how it should be.
ai-sn35:88.10.4_0: This is how it will be.”
ai-sn35:88.11.1_0: “But if they do beat you with a club, what will you think of them then?”
ai-sn35:88.12.1_0: “If they beat me with a club, I’ll think:
ai-sn35:88.12.2_0: ‘This must be because of an abortionist, if these people are clever to me with arms!’
ai-sn35:88.12.3_0: That is how it should be.
ai-sn35:88.12.4_0: This is how it will be.”
ai-sn35:88.13.1_0: “But if they do stab you with a knife, what will you think of them then?”
ai-sn35:88.14.1_0: “If they stab me with a knife, I’ll think:
ai-sn35:88.14.2_0: ‘Oh, these swellers are nice and pleasant, and they don’t take my life with a sharp knife, not some people who kill me.’
ai-sn35:88.14.3_0: That is how it should be.
ai-sn35:88.14.4_0: This is how it will be.”
ai-sn35:88.15.1_0: “But if they do take your life with a sharp knife, what will you think of them then?”
ai-sn35:88.16.1_0: “If they take my life with a sharp knife, I’ll think:
ai-sn35:88.16.2_0: ‘There are disciples of the Buddha who looked for someone to assist with slitting their wrists because they were horrified, repelled, and disgusted with the body and with life. And I have found this without looking!’
ai-sn35:88.16.3_0: That is how it should be.
ai-sn35:88.16.4_0: This is how it will be.”
ai-sn35:88.17.2_0: Having such self-control and peacefulness, you will be quite capable of living in Sunāparanta.
ai-sn35:88.18.1_0: And then Puṇṇa welcomed and agreed with the Buddha’s words. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sunāparanta.
ai-sn35:88.18.3_0: he stayed in a country of Sunāparanta.
ai-sn35:88.18.4_0: Within that rainy season he confirmed around five hundred male and five hundred female lay followers. And within that same rainy season he realized the three knowledges.
ai-sn35:88.18.5_0: And within that same rainy season he realized them.
ai-sn35:88.18.6_0: And that very rainy season he realized the three knowledges.
ai-sn35:88.18.7_0: And within that same rainy season he became completely extinguished.
ai-sn35:88.19.1_0: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:88.19.2_0: “Sir, the gentleman named Puṇṇa, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away.
ai-sn35:88.19.3_0: Where have they been reborn in the next life?”
ai-sn35:88.20.1_0: “Mendicants, Puṇṇa was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
ai-sn35:89.1.1_0: Then Venerable Bāhiya went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:89.1.1_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:
ai-sn35:89.1.2_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:89.2.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:89.4.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:89.6.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:89.6.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:89.8.1_0: “What do you think: are sights permanent or impermanent?”—
ai-sn35:89.9.4_0: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact: is that permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:89.11.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:89.13.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-sn35:89.13.2_0: does someone regard things like this: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-sn35:89.15.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact.
ai-sn35:89.15.2_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:89.15.3_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:89.15.4_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:89.16.1_0: And then Venerable Bāhiya approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-sn35:89.16.2_0: Then Bāhiya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-sn35:89.16.3_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-sn35:89.16.4_0: And Venerable Bāhiya became one of the perfected.
ai-sn35:90.1.1_0: “Mendicants, rebirth is a disease, a boil, a dart.
ai-sn35:90.1.2_0: That’s why the Realized One is staying in the dart of doubt.
ai-sn35:90.1.3_0: In some cases, a mendicant might wish: ‘May I live free of thorns!’
ai-sn35:90.1.4_0: So let them not identify with the eye, let them not identify in the eye, let them not identify from the eye, let them not identify: ‘The eye is mine.’
ai-sn35:90.1.8_0: Let them not identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact. Let them not identify regarding that, let them not identify as that, and let them not identify ‘that is mine.’
ai-sn35:90.2.1_0: Let them not identify the ear ...
ai-sn35:90.2.3_0: Let them not identify with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:90.2.4_0: Let them not identify with tastes ...
ai-sn35:90.2.7_0: Let them not identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by tongue contact. Let them not identify regarding that, let them not identify as that, and let them not identify ‘that is mine.’
ai-sn35:90.3.1_0: Let them not identify with the body ...
ai-sn35:90.3.2_0: Let them not identify with the mind ...
ai-sn35:90.3.6_0: Let them not identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact. Let them not identify regarding that, let them not identify as that, and let them not identify ‘that is mine.’
ai-sn35:90.3.7_0: Let them not identify with all, let them not identify regarding all, let them not identify as all, let them not identify ‘all is mine’.
ai-sn35:90.4.1_0: Not identifying, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.
ai-sn35:90.4.2_0: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
ai-sn35:90.4.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:91.1.1_0: “Mendicants, rebirth is a disease, a boil, a dart.
ai-sn35:91.1.2_0: That’s why the Realized One is staying in the dart of doubt.
ai-sn35:91.1.3_0: In some cases, a mendicant might wish: ‘May I live free of thorns!’
ai-sn35:91.1.4_0: So let them not identify with the eye, let them not identify in the eye, let them not identify from the eye, let them not identify: ‘The eye is mine.’
ai-sn35:91.1.5_0: Let them not identify with sights ...
ai-sn35:91.1.8_0: Let them not identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact. Let them not identify regarding that, let them not identify as that, and let them not identify ‘that is mine.’
ai-sn35:91.1.9_0: But then they identify with something else they identify, they identify regarding that, they identify as that, and identify that,
ai-sn35:91.1.10_0: The world is attached to being, taking pleasure only in being, yet it becomes something else.
ai-sn35:91.2.1_0: Let them not identify with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:91.2.2_0: Let them not identify with tastes ...
ai-sn35:91.2.5_0: Let them not identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by tongue contact. Let them not identify regarding that, let them not identify as that, and let them not identify ‘that is mine.’
ai-sn35:91.2.6_0: But then they identify with something else they identify, they identify regarding that, they identify as that, and identify that,
ai-sn35:91.2.6_1: The world is attached to being, taking pleasure only in being, yet it becomes something else.
ai-sn35:91.3.1_0: Let them not identify with the mind ...
ai-sn35:91.3.4_0: Let them not identify with the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact. Let them not identify in that, let them not identify as that, and let them not identify: ‘That is mine.’
ai-sn35:91.3.5_0: But then they identify with something else they identify, they identify regarding that, they identify as that, and identify that,
ai-sn35:91.3.6_0: The world is attached to being, taking pleasure only in being, yet it becomes something else.
ai-sn35:91.4.1_0: As far as the aggregates, elements, and sense fields extend, they don’t identify with that, they don’t identify in that, they don’t identify as that, and they don’t identify: ‘That is mine.’
ai-sn35:91.4.2_0: Not identifying, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.
ai-sn35:91.4.3_0: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
ai-sn35:91.4.4_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:92.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you a duality.
ai-sn35:92.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:92.1.4_0: It’s just the eye and sights, the ear and sounds, the nose and smells, the tongue and tastes, the body and touches, and the mind and thoughts.
ai-sn35:92.2.2_0: ‘I’ll reject this duality and describe another duality.’ They’d have no grounds for that,
ai-sn35:92.2.3_0: they’d be stumped by questions, and, in addition, they’d get frustrated.
ai-sn35:93.1.1_0: “Mendicants, consciousness exists dependent on a duality.
ai-sn35:93.1.3_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights.
ai-sn35:93.1.4_0: The eye is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.5_0: Sights are impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.6_0: And that is where and intexts and toppling is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.7_0: Eye consciousness is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.8_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to eye consciousness are also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.9_0: But since eye consciousness has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.1.10_0: The meeting, coming together, and joining together of these three things is called eye contact.
ai-sn35:93.1.11_0: Eye contact is also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.12_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to eye contact are also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.1.13_0: But since eye contact has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.1.14_0: When a touch is touch, they perceive it as touch.
ai-sn35:93.1.15_0: So these things are tottering and toppling; they’re impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.1_0: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes.
ai-sn35:93.2.3_0: and tastes are impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.4_0: And that is where and intexts and toppling is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.5_0: and tongue consciousness are impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.6_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to consciousness are also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.7_0: But since tongue consciousness has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.2.8_0: The meeting, coming together, and joining together of these three things is called tongue.
ai-sn35:93.2.9_0: The tongue is also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.10_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to tongue contact are also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.2.11_0: But since tongue contact has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.2.12_0: When a touch is touch, they perceive it as touch.
ai-sn35:93.2.13_0: So these things are tottering and toppling; they’re impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.1_0: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts.
ai-sn35:93.3.2_0: The mind is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.3_0: and thoughts are impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.4_0: And that is where and intexts and toppling is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.5_0: Mind consciousness is impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.6_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to mind consciousness are also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.7_0: But since mind consciousness has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.3.8_0: The meeting, coming together, and joining together of these three things is called mind contact.
ai-sn35:93.3.9_0: Mind contact is also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.10_0: And the causes and conditions that give rise to mind contact are also impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.11_0: But since mind contact has arisen dependent on conditions that are impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:93.3.12_0: When a touch is touch, they perceive it as touch.
ai-sn35:93.3.13_0: So these things are tottering and toppling; they’re impermanent, perishing, and changing.
ai-sn35:93.3.14_0: This is how consciousness exists dependent on a duality.”
ai-sn35:93.3.16_0: The fourth sub-chapter on the Channa is finished.
ai-sn35:94.1.2_0: “Mendicants, these six fields of contact bring suffering when they’re untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
ai-sn35:94.1.3_0: What are the teachings grouped by six?
ai-sn35:94.1.4_0: The field of eye contact brings suffering when it’s untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
ai-sn35:94.1.5_0: The field of ear contact ... nose contact ... tongue contact ... body contact ...
ai-sn35:94.1.6_0: The field of mind contact brings suffering when it’s untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
ai-sn35:94.1.7_0: These six fields of contact bring suffering when they’re untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
ai-sn35:94.2.1_0: These six fields of contact bring happiness when they’re well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
ai-sn35:94.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by six?
ai-sn35:94.2.3_0: The field of eye contact brings happiness when it’s well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
ai-sn35:94.2.4_0: The field of ear contact ... nose contact ... tongue contact ... body contact ...
ai-sn35:94.2.5_0: The field of mind contact brings happiness when it’s well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
ai-sn35:94.2.6_0: These six fields of contact bring happiness when they’re well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.”
ai-sn35:94.2.7_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:94.3.1_0: “Mendicants, it’s just the six fields of contact
ai-sn35:94.3.2_0: that lead the unrestrained to suffering.
ai-sn35:94.3.3_0: Those who understand how to restrain them
ai-sn35:94.3.4_0: live with faith as partner, uncorrupted.
ai-sn35:94.4.3_0: get rid of all manner of desire for the pleasant,
ai-sn35:94.4.4_0: without hating what you don’t like.
ai-sn35:94.5.1_0: When you’ve heard sounds both liked and disliked,
ai-sn35:94.5.2_0: don’t fall under the thrall of sounds you like,
ai-sn35:94.5.3_0: get rid of hate for the unliked,
ai-sn35:94.5.4_0: without hating what you don’t like.
ai-sn35:94.6.1_0: When you’ve smelled a pleasant, fragrant scent,
ai-sn35:94.6.2_0: and one that’s foul and unpleasant,
ai-sn35:94.6.3_0: get rid of repulsion for the unpleasant,
ai-sn35:94.6.4_0: while not yielding to desire for the pleasant.
ai-sn35:94.7.1_0: When you’ve enjoyed a sweet, delicious taste,
ai-sn35:94.7.2_0: and sometimes those that are bitter,
ai-sn35:94.7.3_0: don’t be attached to enjoying sweet tastes,
ai-sn35:94.8.1_0: Don’t be intoxicated by a pleasant touch,
ai-sn35:94.8.2_0: and don’t tremble at a painful touch.
ai-sn35:94.8.3_0: Look with equanimity at the duality of pleasant and painful contacts,
ai-sn35:94.9.1_0: People generally let their perceptions proliferate;
ai-sn35:94.9.2_0: perceiving and proliferating, they are attracted.
ai-sn35:94.9.3_0: When you’ve rejected all thoughts of the lay life,
ai-sn35:94.10.1_0: And so too, when the mind is developed,
ai-sn35:94.10.2_0: it doesn’t waver at contacts at all.
ai-sn35:94.10.3_0: Mendicants, those who have mastered greed and hate
ai-sn35:94.10.5_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn35:95.1.1_0: Then Venerable Māluṅkyaputta went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:95.1.1_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and told the Buddha of his thoughts. He then continued:
ai-sn35:95.1.2_0: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”
ai-sn35:95.2.1_0: “Well now, Māluṅkyaputta, what are we to say to the young monks,
ai-sn35:95.2.2_0: when even an old man like you, elderly and senior, advanced in years, having reached the final stage of life, asks the Realized One for brief advice?”
ai-sn35:95.3.1_0: “Sir, even though I’m an old man, elderly and senior,
ai-sn35:95.3.2_0: may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief! May the Holy one please teach me in brief! Hopefully I can understand the meaning of what the Buddha says.
ai-sn35:95.3.2_1: Hopefully I can be an heir of the Buddha’s teaching!”
ai-sn35:95.4.2_0: Do you have any seen or heard of sights known by the eye that you haven’t seen, you’ve never seen before, you don’t see, and you don’t see.
ai-sn35:95.4.2_1: Do you have any desire or greed or fondness for oneself?”
ai-sn35:95.5.1_0: “Do you have heard sounds known by the ear ...
ai-sn35:95.5.1_1: Do you have any desire or greed or fondness for oneself?”
ai-sn35:95.6.1_1: Do you have any desire or greed or fondness for oneself?”
ai-sn35:95.7.1_1: Do you have any desire or greed or fondness for oneself?”
ai-sn35:95.8.1_1: Do you have any desire or greed or fondness for oneself?”
ai-sn35:95.9.1_0: thoughts known by the mind that you haven’t known, you’ve never known before, you don’t know, and you don’t think would be known?
ai-sn35:95.9.1_1: Do you have any desire or greed or fondness for oneself?”
ai-sn35:95.10.1_0: “In that case, when it comes to things that are to be seen, heard, thought, and known: in the seen will be merely the seen; in the heard will be merely the heard; in the thought will be merely the thought; in the known will be merely the known.
ai-sn35:95.10.7_0: you won’t be in this world or the world beyond or in between the two.
ai-sn35:95.11.1_0: “This is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement:
ai-sn35:95.12.1_0: ‘When you see a sight, mindfulness is lost
ai-sn35:95.12.2_0: When you attend improperly to the foundation of meditation,
ai-sn35:95.12.3_0: With a mind full of lust,
ai-sn35:95.13.6_0: one is said to be extinguishment.
ai-sn35:95.14.1_0: When you hear a sound, mindfulness is lost
ai-sn35:95.14.2_0: When you attend improperly to the foundation of meditation,
ai-sn35:95.14.3_0: With a mind full of lust,
ai-sn35:95.15.2_0: with no sound for any existence.
