ai-sn35:95.42.1_0: And then Venerable Māluṅkyaputta approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
ai-sn35:95.42.2_0: Then Māluṅkyaputta, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-sn35:95.42.3_0: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.”
ai-sn35:95.42.4_0: And Venerable Māluṅkyaputta became one of the perfected.
ai-sn35:96.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you who is liable to decline, who is not liable to decline, and the six fields of mastery.
ai-sn35:96.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:96.1.3_0: And how is someone liable to decline?
ai-sn35:96.1.4_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.1.5_0: Suppose that mendicant tolerates them and doesn’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them. They should understand:
ai-sn35:96.1.7_0: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’
ai-sn35:96.2.1_0: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:96.2.2_0: knows a thought with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.2.3_0: Suppose that mendicant tolerates them and doesn’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them. They should understand:
ai-sn35:96.2.5_0: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’
ai-sn35:96.2.6_0: That’s how someone is liable to decline.
ai-sn35:96.3.1_0: And how is someone not liable to decline?
ai-sn35:96.3.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.3.3_0: If that mendicant doesn’t tolerate them, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them, they should understand:
ai-sn35:96.3.4_0: ‘May I not decline in skillful qualities!’
ai-sn35:96.3.5_0: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’
ai-sn35:96.4.1_0: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:96.4.2_0: knows a thought with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.4.3_0: If that mendicant doesn’t tolerate them, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them, they should understand:
ai-sn35:96.4.4_0: ‘May I not decline in skillful qualities!’
ai-sn35:96.4.5_0: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’
ai-sn35:96.4.6_0: That’s how someone is not liable to decline.
ai-sn35:96.5.1_0: And what are the six fields of mastery?
ai-sn35:96.5.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.5.5_0: For this is what the Buddha calls a field of mastery.’ ...
ai-sn35:96.5.6_0: Furthermore, when a mendicant knows a thought with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:96.5.9_0: For this is what the Buddha calls a field of mastery.’
ai-sn35:96.5.10_0: These are the six fields of mastery.”
ai-sn35:97.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you who lives negligently and who lives diligently.
ai-sn35:97.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:97.1.3_0: And how does someone live negligently?
ai-sn35:97.1.4_0: When you live with the eye faculty unrestrained, your mind becomes polluted when it comes to sights known by the eye.
ai-sn35:97.1.5_0: But their mind’s joy is not glad.
ai-sn35:97.1.6_0: When there are no joy, there is no joy.
ai-sn35:97.1.7_0: When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.
ai-sn35:97.1.8_0: When there is no tranquility there’s no suffering.
ai-sn35:97.1.9_0: Painful mind is not immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:97.1.10_0: When their mind is not immersed in samādhi,
ai-sn35:97.1.11_0: Because principles have not become clear, you’re considered to live negligently.
ai-sn35:97.1.12_0: When you live with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:97.1.13_0: has ended the mind, so full of peace. He teaches Dhamma:
ai-sn35:97.1.15_0: mind faculty unrestrained, your mind becomes polluted when it comes to thoughts known by the mind.
ai-sn35:97.1.16_0: But their mind’s joy is not glad.
ai-sn35:97.1.17_0: When there are no joy, there is no joy.
ai-sn35:97.1.18_0: When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.
ai-sn35:97.1.19_0: When there is no tranquility there’s no suffering.
ai-sn35:97.1.20_0: Painful mind is not immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:97.1.21_0: When their mind is not immersed in samādhi,
ai-sn35:97.1.22_0: Because principles have not become clear, you’re considered to live negligently.
ai-sn35:97.2.1_0: And how does someone live diligently?
ai-sn35:97.2.2_0: When you live with the eye faculty restrained, your mind doesn’t become polluted when it comes to sights known by the eye.
ai-sn35:97.2.3_0: That’s how their mind is born of joy.
ai-sn35:97.2.4_0: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up.
ai-sn35:97.2.5_0: the body is full of tranquility.
ai-sn35:97.2.6_0: They live happily in the present life.
ai-sn35:97.2.7_0: They feel bliss, when they’re happy, their mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:97.2.9_0: Because principles have become clear, you’re considered to live diligently.
ai-sn35:97.2.10_0: When you live with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:97.2.12_0: mind faculty restrained, your mind doesn’t become polluted when it comes to thoughts known by the mind.
ai-sn35:97.2.13_0: That’s how their mind is born of joy.
ai-sn35:97.2.14_0: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up.
ai-sn35:97.2.15_0: the body is full of tranquility.
ai-sn35:97.2.16_0: They live happily in the present life.
ai-sn35:97.2.17_0: They feel bliss, when they’re happy, their mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:97.2.19_0: Because principles have become clear, you’re considered to live diligently.
ai-sn35:98.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you who is restrained and who is unrestrained.
ai-sn35:98.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:98.1.3_0: And how is restraint of restraint?
ai-sn35:98.1.4_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:98.1.5_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them, they should understand:
ai-sn35:98.1.7_0: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’
ai-sn35:98.1.8_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:98.1.9_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:98.1.10_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them, they should understand:
ai-sn35:98.1.12_0: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’
ai-sn35:98.2.2_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:98.2.3_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they should understand:
ai-sn35:98.2.5_0: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’
ai-sn35:98.2.6_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:98.2.7_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:98.2.8_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they should understand:
ai-sn35:98.2.10_0: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’
ai-sn35:98.2.11_0: This is how someone is restrained.”
ai-sn35:99.1.2_0: A mendicant with immersion truly understands.
ai-sn35:99.1.3_0: And what do they truly understand?

ai-sn35:99.1.13_0: the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is impermanent.

ai-sn35:100.1.8_0: the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is impermanent.

ai-sn35:103.1.1_0: “Mendicants, Uddaka, son of Rāma, used to say:
ai-sn35:103.1.2_0: ‘This for sure is the knowledge master! This for sure is the conqueror of all! This for sure is the boil’s root dug out, never dug out before!’
ai-sn35:103.1.3_0: Even though Uddaka, son of Rāma, was no knowledge master, he said ‘I’m a knowledge master.’ Though he was no conqueror of all, he said ‘I’m conqueror of all.’ And though the boil’s root was not dug out, he said ‘I’ve dug out the boil’s root.’
ai-sn35:103.1.4_0: But that’s how a mendicant would rightly say:
ai-sn35:103.1.5_0: ‘This for sure is the knowledge master! This for sure is the conqueror of all! This for sure is the boil’s root dug out, never dug out before!’
ai-sn35:103.2.1_0: And how is someone a knowledge master?
ai-sn35:103.2.2_0: It’s when a mendicant truly understands the six fields of contact’s origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
ai-sn35:103.2.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is a knowledge master.
ai-sn35:103.3.1_0: And how is a mendicant a conqueror of all?
ai-sn35:103.3.2_0: It’s when a mendicant comes to be freed by not grasping after truly understanding these six sense fields’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
ai-sn35:103.3.3_0: That’s how a mendicant is a conqueror of all.
ai-sn35:103.4.1_0: And how has a mendicant dug out the boil’s root, which was never dug out before?
ai-sn35:103.4.2_0: ‘Covet’ is a term for this body made up of the four primary elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
ai-sn35:103.4.3_0: ‘Boil’s root’ is a term for craving.
ai-sn35:103.4.4_0: It’s when a mendicant has given up craving, cut it off at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn35:103.4.5_0: That’s how a mendicant has dug out the boil’s root, which was never dug out before.
ai-sn35:103.5.1_0: Uddaka, son of Rāma, used to say:
ai-sn35:103.5.2_0: ‘This for sure is the knowledge master! This for sure is the conqueror of all! This for sure is the boil’s root dug out, never dug out before!’
ai-sn35:103.5.3_0: Even though Uddaka, son of Rāma, was no knowledge master, he said ‘I’m a knowledge master.’ Though he was no conqueror of all, he said ‘I’m conqueror of all.’ And though the boil’s root was not dug out, he said ‘I’ve dug out the boil’s root.’
ai-sn35:103.5.4_0: ‘That’s the boil’s root, which was never dug out before.’
ai-sn35:103.5.5_0: But that’s how a mendicant would rightly say:
ai-sn35:103.5.6_0: ‘This for sure is the knowledge master! This for sure is the conqueror of all! This for sure is the boil’s root dug out, never dug out before!’”
ai-sn35:103.5.8_0: The fifth sub-chapter on nakedness is finished.
ai-sn35:103.6.4_0: Not to make two out of us dust.
ai-sn35:103.6.5_0: The second sub-chapter on the six sense fields is finished.

ai-sn35:104.1.2_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition of the teaching, an explanation of one who has reached sanctuary.
ai-sn35:104.1.3_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:104.1.4_0: And what is an exposition of the teaching, an explanation of one who has reached sanctuary?
ai-sn35:104.1.5_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:104.1.6_0: He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn35:104.1.7_0: He teaches meditation for giving them up. That’s why the Realized One is called one who has reached sanctuary. ...
ai-sn35:104.1.8_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:104.1.9_0: He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future.
ai-sn35:104.1.10_0: He teaches meditation for giving them up. That’s why the Realized One is called one who has reached sanctuary.
ai-sn35:104.1.11_0: This is an exposition of the teaching, an explanation of one who has reached sanctuary.”
ai-sn35:104.1.12_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn35:105.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what, do pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
ai-sn35:105.2.1_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. ...”
ai-sn35:105.3.1_0: “Mendicants, when there’s an eye, because of grasping the eye, pleasure and pain arise in oneself. ...
ai-sn35:105.3.2_0: When there’s a mind, because of grasping the mind, pleasure and pain arise in oneself.
ai-sn35:105.3.4_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:105.5.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:105.7.1_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
ai-sn35:105.9.1_0: “Is the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ... mind ...
ai-sn35:105.11.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:105.13.1_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
ai-sn35:105.15.1_0: Is the mind permanent or impermanent?”
ai-sn35:105.17.1_0: “But if they’re impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-sn35:105.19.1_0: “But by not grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would such a pleasure and pain arise in oneself?”
ai-sn35:105.21.1_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn35:105.21.2_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:105.21.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:106.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the origin and the ending of suffering.
ai-sn35:106.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:106.1.3_0: And what, mendicants, is the origin of suffering?
ai-sn35:106.1.4_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:106.1.5_0: Contact is a condition for feeling.
ai-sn35:106.1.6_0: Feeling is a condition for craving.
ai-sn35:106.1.7_0: This is the origin of suffering ...
ai-sn35:106.1.8_0: Tongue consciousness arises dependent on the tongue and tastes. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:106.1.9_0: Contact is a condition for feeling.
ai-sn35:106.1.10_0: Feeling is a condition for craving.
ai-sn35:106.1.11_0: Mind consciousness arises dependent on the mind and thoughts.
ai-sn35:106.1.13_0: Contact is a condition for feeling.
ai-sn35:106.1.14_0: Feeling is a condition for craving.
ai-sn35:106.1.15_0: This is the origin of suffering.
ai-sn35:106.2.1_0: And what is the ending of suffering?
ai-sn35:106.2.2_0: Eye consciousness arises dependent on the eye and sights. The meeting of the three is contact.
ai-sn35:106.2.3_0: Contact is a condition for feeling.
ai-sn35:106.2.4_0: Feeling is a condition for craving.
ai-sn35:106.2.5_0: It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over;
ai-sn35:106.2.6_0: when grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.
ai-sn35:106.2.7_0: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.
ai-sn35:106.2.8_0: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.

ai-sn35:108.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, do people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”

ai-sn35:108.16.1_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
ai-sn35:108.16.2_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:108.16.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”

ai-sn35:114.0.2_0: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation
ai-sn35:114.1.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:114.1.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:114.1.3_0: they’re called a mendicant who has fallen under Māra’s sway, and released from Māra’s snare.
ai-sn35:114.1.4_0: They’re bound by Māra, and the Wicked One can do what he wants with them.
ai-sn35:114.2.1_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:114.2.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:114.2.3_0: they’re called a mendicant who has fallen under Māra’s sway, and released from Māra’s snare.

ai-sn35:114.3.1_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

ai-sn35:114.3.3_0: they’re called a mendicant who has fallen under Māra’s sway, and released from Māra’s snare.

ai-sn35:114.4.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:114.4.3_0: they’re called a mendicant not trapped in Māra’s lair, not fallen under Māra’s sway, and released from Māra’s snare.
ai-sn35:114.4.4_0: They’re freed from Māra, and the Wicked One can do what he wants with them.

ai-sn35:116.0.3_0: 116. Traveling to the End of the World
ai-sn35:116.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.
ai-sn35:116.1.2_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.”
ai-sn35:116.1.3_0: and he got up from his seat and entered his dwelling.
ai-sn35:116.1.4_0: And then, not long after the Buddha had left, those mendicants thought:
ai-sn35:116.1.5_0: “The Buddha gave this brief summary, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail. ...
ai-sn35:116.1.6_0: ‘I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.”
ai-sn35:116.1.7_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.’
ai-sn35:116.1.8_0: What is the detailed meaning of this brief passage for recitation?”
ai-sn35:116.2.2_0: “This Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.
ai-sn35:116.2.3_0: You are capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-sn35:116.3.1_0: Then those mendicants went to Ānanda
ai-sn35:116.3.1_1: went with Ānanda and exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn35:116.3.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side,
ai-sn35:116.3.2_1: Then the Buddha said to him:
ai-sn35:116.4.1_0: “The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail.
ai-sn35:116.4.2_0: ‘Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.
ai-sn35:116.4.3_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.’
ai-sn35:116.4.4_0: And soon after the Buddha had left, we thought,
ai-sn35:116.4.5_0: The Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:
ai-sn35:116.4.6_0: I say, Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.
ai-sn35:116.4.7_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.
ai-sn35:116.4.8_0: What is the detailed meaning of this brief passage for recitation?’
ai-sn35:116.4.10_0: ‘This Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.
ai-sn35:116.4.11_0: You are capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-sn35:116.5.1_0: “Reverends, suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But he’d pass over the roots and trunk, imagining that the heartwood should be sought in the branches and leaves.
ai-sn35:116.5.2_0: That’s how for the venerables were face to face with the Buddha, they passed him by, imagining that you should ask me about this matter.
ai-sn35:116.5.3_0: For he is the Buddha, who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is supreme. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One.
ai-sn35:116.5.4_0: The eye is produced by the eye, who speaks the truth, and who speaks in accordance with the Teaching; the Realized One is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One.
ai-sn35:116.5.5_0: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.
ai-sn35:116.5.6_0: You should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”
ai-sn35:116.6.1_0: “Certainly he is the Buddha, who knows and sees. He is vision, he is knowledge, he is the truth, he is supreme. He is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One.
ai-sn35:116.6.2_0: The eye is produced by the eye, who speaks the truth, and who speaks in accordance with the Teaching; the Realized One is the teacher, the proclaimer, the elucidator of meaning, the bestower of the deathless, the lord of truth, the Realized One.
ai-sn35:116.6.3_0: That was the time to approach the Buddha and ask about this matter.
ai-sn35:116.6.4_0: You should have remembered it in line with the Buddha’s answer.
ai-sn35:116.6.5_0: Still, Venerable Ānanda is praised by the Buddha and esteemed by his sensible spiritual companions.
ai-sn35:116.6.6_0: You are capable of explaining in detail the meaning of this brief passage for recitation given by the Buddha.
ai-sn35:116.6.7_0: Please explain this, if it’s no trouble.”
ai-sn35:116.7.1_0: “Then listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn35:116.8.1_0: “Reverends, the Buddha gave this brief summary, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:
ai-sn35:116.8.2_0: ‘Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.
ai-sn35:116.8.3_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.’
ai-sn35:116.8.4_0: This is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary.
ai-sn35:116.8.5_0: They perceive the world and conceive the world.
ai-sn35:116.8.6_0: This is called the world in the training of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:116.8.7_0: And through what in the world do you perceive the world and conceive the world?
ai-sn35:116.8.8_0: Through the eye in the world you perceive the world and conceive the world.
ai-sn35:116.8.11_0: Through the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:116.8.13_0: mind in the world you perceive the world and conceive the world.
ai-sn35:116.8.14_0: They perceive the world and conceive the world.
ai-sn35:116.8.15_0: This is called the world in the training of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:116.8.16_0: When the Buddha gave this brief passage for recitation, then entered his dwelling without explaining the meaning in detail:
ai-sn35:116.8.17_0: ‘Mendicants, I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by traveling.
ai-sn35:116.8.18_0: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.’
ai-sn35:116.8.19_0: That is how I understand the detailed meaning of this summary.
ai-sn35:116.8.20_0: If you wish, you may go to the Buddha and ask him about this.
ai-sn35:116.8.21_0: You should remember it in line with the Buddha’s answer.”

ai-sn35:118.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

ai-sn35:118.1.2_2: He went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
ai-sn35:118.1.3_0: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
ai-sn35:118.1.4_0: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?” ...

ai-sn35:118.2.3_0: This consciousness relies on that and grasps it.

ai-sn35:120.0.2_0: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation
ai-sn35:120.0.3_0: While living at home he was dwelling placed against the Sāriputta.
ai-sn35:120.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn35:120.1.2_0: Then a certain mendicant went up to Venerable Sāriputta,
ai-sn35:120.1.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:120.1.4_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, a mendicant pupil of mine has resigned the training and returned to a lesser life.”
ai-sn35:120.2.1_0: “That’s how it is, reverend, when someone doesn’t guard the sense doors, eats too much, and is not committed to wakefulness.
ai-sn35:120.2.2_0: It’s not possible for such a mendicant to maintain the full and pure spiritual life for the rest of their life.
ai-sn35:120.2.3_0: But it is possible for a mendicant to maintain the full and pure spiritual life for the rest of their life if they guard the sense doors, eat in moderation, and are committed to wakefulness.
ai-sn35:120.3.1_0: And how does someone guard the sense doors?
ai-sn35:120.3.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:120.3.3_0: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving restraint over it.
ai-sn35:120.3.4_0: When hearing a sound with the ear ...
ai-sn35:120.3.5_0: When smelling an odor with the nose ...
ai-sn35:120.3.6_0: Tasting a flavor with his tongue ...
ai-sn35:120.3.7_0: Feeling a touch with his body ...
ai-sn35:120.3.8_0: Knowing a thought with his mind, he doesn’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:120.3.9_0: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
ai-sn35:120.3.10_0: That’s how someone guards the sense doors.
ai-sn35:120.4.1_0: And how does someone eat in moderation?
ai-sn35:120.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant reflects properly on the food that they eat:
ai-sn35:120.4.3_0: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice.
ai-sn35:120.4.3_1: In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will live blamelessly and at ease.’
ai-sn35:120.4.4_0: That’s how someone eats in moderation.
ai-sn35:120.5.1_0: And how is someone committed to wakefulness?
ai-sn35:120.5.2_0: It’s when a mendicant practices walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying their mind from obstacles.
ai-sn35:120.5.3_0: In the evening, he continues to practice walking and sitting meditation.
ai-sn35:120.5.4_0: In the middle of the night, they lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
ai-sn35:120.5.5_0: In the last part of the night, he gets up and continues to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying his mind from obstacles.
ai-sn35:120.5.6_0: That’s how someone is committed to wakefulness.
ai-sn35:120.5.7_0: So you should train like this:
ai-sn35:120.5.8_0: ‘We will guard the sense doors, eat in moderation, and be committed to wakefulness.’
ai-sn35:121.0.2_0: 12. The World and the Kinds of Sensual Stimulation

ai-sn35:121.51.1_0: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they become disillusioned with anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises conditioned by eye contact.
ai-sn35:121.51.2_0: They grow disillusioned with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:121.52.1_0: They grow disillusioned with the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact. And they grow disillusioned with anything included in feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:121.52.2_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:121.52.3_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:121.53.1_0: This is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:121.53.2_0: Satisfied, Venerable Rāhula was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:121.53.3_0: And while this discourse was being spoken, the mind of Venerable Rāhula was freed from the corruptions without grasping.
ai-sn35:121.53.4_0: And the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in those thousands of deities:
ai-sn35:121.53.5_0: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”

ai-sn35:122.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the fetters and the fetter of thoughts.

ai-sn35:122.1.5_0: These are called the things that are prone to being fettered.

ai-sn35:122.1.8_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

ai-sn35:127.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
ai-sn35:127.1.2_0: King Udena then went to Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja
ai-sn35:127.1.2_1: Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja went to exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn35:127.1.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:127.1.3_1: He went to Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja and said to him,
ai-sn35:127.1.4_0: “Master Bhāradvāja, there are these young monks who are youthful, black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life; and they’ve never played around with sensual pleasures. What is the cause, what is the reason why they practice the full and pure spiritual life as long as they live, maintaining it for a long time?”
ai-sn35:127.1.5_0: “Great king, this is the extent to which one who knows and sees, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ai-sn35:127.1.6_0: ‘Please, monks, think of women your mother’s age as your mother. Think of women your sister’s age as your sister. And think of women your daughter’s age as your daughter.’
ai-sn35:127.1.7_0: This is a cause, great king, this is a reason why these young monks practice the full and pure spiritual life as long as they live, maintaining it for a long time.”
ai-sn35:127.2.1_0: “But Master Bhāradvāja, the mind is wanton.
ai-sn35:127.2.2_0: Sometimes thoughts of desire come up even for women your mother’s age, your sister’s age, or your daughter’s age.
ai-sn35:127.2.3_0: Is there another cause, another reason why these young monks live the full and pure spiritual life for their entire life ...
ai-sn35:127.3.1_0: “Great king, this is the extent to which one who knows and sees, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ai-sn35:127.3.2_0: ‘Please, monks, examine your own body up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.
ai-sn35:127.3.3_0: In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’
ai-sn35:127.3.4_0: This is also a cause, great king, this is a reason why these young monks live the full and pure spiritual life for their entire life,
ai-sn35:127.3.4_1: they are traveling along the road.”
ai-sn35:127.3.5_0: “This is easy to do for those mendicants who have developed their physical endurance, ethics, mind, and wisdom.
ai-sn35:127.3.6_0: But it’s hard to do for those mendicants who have not developed their physical endurance, ethics, mind, and wisdom.
ai-sn35:127.3.7_0: Sometimes I plan to focus on something as ugly, but only its beauty comes to mind.
ai-sn35:127.3.8_0: Is there another cause, another reason why these young monks live the full and pure spiritual life for their entire life ...
ai-sn35:127.4.1_0: “Great king, this is the extent to which one who knows and sees, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ai-sn35:127.4.2_0: ‘Please, monks, live with sense doors guarded.
ai-sn35:127.4.3_0: When you see a sight with your eyes, don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:127.4.4_0: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming.
ai-sn35:127.4.4_1: For this reason, protect the faculty of sight,
ai-sn35:127.4.4_2: For this reason, practice restraint, protect the faculty of sight, and achieve its restraint.
ai-sn35:127.4.5_0: When I heard a sound with my ears ...
ai-sn35:127.4.6_0: When smelling an odor with the nose ...
ai-sn35:127.4.7_0: Tasting a flavor with his tongue ...
ai-sn35:127.4.8_0: Feeling a touch with his body ...
ai-sn35:127.4.9_0: When you know a thought with your mind, don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:127.4.10_0: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming.
ai-sn35:127.4.10_2: For this reason, practice restraint, protect the faculty of mind.’
ai-sn35:127.4.11_0: This is also a cause, great king, this is a reason why these young monks practice the full and pure spiritual life as long as they live, maintaining it for a long time.”
ai-sn35:127.5.2_0: How well this was said by the Buddha!
ai-sn35:127.5.3_0: This is the real cause, this is the reason why these young monks practice the full and pure spiritual life as long as they live, maintaining it for a long time.
ai-sn35:127.5.4_0: For sometimes I too enter the harem with unprotected body, speech, mind, mindfulness, and sense faculties. At those times powerful thoughts of desire get the better of me.
ai-sn35:127.5.5_0: But sometimes I enter the harem with protected body, speech, mind, mindfulness, and sense faculties. At those times such thoughts of desire don’t get the better of me.
ai-sn35:127.5.7_0: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Bhāradvāja has made the teaching clear in many ways.
ai-sn35:127.5.7_1: those with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-sn35:127.5.7_2: just so have you made the Teaching clear in many ways.
ai-sn35:127.5.8_0: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-sn35:127.5.9_0: From this day forth, may Master Bhāradvāja remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-sn35:128.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn35:128.1.2_0: Then the householder Soṇa went up to the Buddha.
ai-sn35:128.1.3_0: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
ai-sn35:128.1.4_0: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?” ...
ai-sn35:128.1.5_0: (This should be told in full as in SN 35.124.)
ai-sn35:128.1.6_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life.
ai-sn35:129.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
ai-sn35:129.1.2_0: Then the householder Ghosita went up to Venerable Ānanda,
ai-sn35:129.1.2_1: He went to Ānanda, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
ai-sn35:129.1.3_0: “Sir, Ānanda, they speak of ‘the diversity of elements’.
ai-sn35:129.1.4_0: In what way did the Buddha speak of the diversity of elements?”
ai-sn35:129.1.5_0: “Householder, the eye element is found, as are agreeable sights, and eye consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.6_0: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn35:129.1.7_0: The eye element is found, as are disagreeable sights, and eye consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.8_0: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn35:129.1.9_0: The eye element is found, as are sights that are a basis for equanimity, and eye consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.10_0: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn35:129.1.12_0: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn35:129.1.14_0: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn35:129.1.16_0: Neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn35:129.1.17_0: mind element is found, as are agreeable thoughts, and mind consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.18_0: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn35:129.1.19_0: The mind element is found, as are disagreeable thoughts, and mind consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.20_0: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn35:129.1.21_0: The mind element is found, as are thoughts that are a basis for equanimity, and mind consciousness.
ai-sn35:129.1.22_0: There is eye consciousness; and neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn35:129.1.23_0: That’s how the diversity of elements defined by the Buddha.”
ai-sn35:130.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis near Kuraraghara on Steep Mountain.
ai-sn35:130.1.2_0: Then the householder Hāliddikāni went up to Venerable Mahākaccāna ...
ai-sn35:130.1.2_1: He went up to Venerable Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
ai-sn35:130.1.3_0: “Sir, this was said by the Buddha:
ai-sn35:130.1.4_0: ‘Diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts,
ai-sn35:130.1.4_1: diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings.’
ai-sn35:130.1.5_0: How does diversity of elements give rise to diversity of contacts?
ai-sn35:130.1.5_1: diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings.”
ai-sn35:130.1.6_0: “Householder, take a mendicant who sees a sight with their eyes. They understand: ‘This is a basis for happiness.’
ai-sn35:130.1.7_0: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn35:130.1.8_0: Then they see a sight and understand it to be disagreeable.
ai-sn35:130.1.9_0: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn35:130.1.10_0: Then they see a sight and understand it to be a basis for equanimity.
ai-sn35:130.1.11_0: There is eye consciousness; and neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn35:130.2.1_0: Furthermore, a mendicant hears a sound with the ear ...
ai-sn35:130.2.2_0: When I smelled an odor with my nose ...
ai-sn35:130.2.3_0: tastes a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-sn35:130.2.4_0: feels a touch with the body ...
ai-sn35:130.2.5_0: knows a thought with the mind and understands it to be agreeable.
ai-sn35:130.2.6_0: There is mind consciousness; and pleasant feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as pleasant.
ai-sn35:130.2.7_0: Then they know a thought and understand it to be disagreeable.
ai-sn35:130.2.8_0: There is mind consciousness; and painful feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as painful.
ai-sn35:130.2.9_0: Then they know a thought and understand it to be a basis for equanimity.
ai-sn35:130.2.10_0: There is eye consciousness; and neutral feeling arises dependent on a contact to be experienced as neutral.
ai-sn35:130.2.11_0: That’s how diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts.
ai-sn35:130.2.11_1: diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings.”
ai-sn35:131.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Bhaggas on Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.
ai-sn35:131.1.2_0: Then the householder Nakula’s father went up to the Buddha ...
ai-sn35:131.1.2_1: Nakula’s father said to the Buddha,
ai-sn35:131.1.3_0: “Sir, what is the cause, what is the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life?
ai-sn35:131.1.4_0: What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings are fully extinguished in the present life?” ...

ai-sn35:131.1.8_0: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.
ai-sn35:131.1.9_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:131.1.10_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:131.1.11_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:131.1.12_0: This consciousness relies on that and grasps it.
ai-sn35:131.1.13_0: A mendicant with grasping does not become extinguished.
ai-sn35:131.1.14_0: That’s the cause, that’s the reason why some sentient beings aren’t fully extinguished in the present life.

ai-sn35:131.2.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.

ai-sn35:131.2.6_0: thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:131.2.7_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.

ai-sn35:132.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in the land of the Avantis in a wilderness hut near Makkarakaṭa.
ai-sn35:132.1.2_0: Then several youths, students of the brahmin Lohicca, approached Mahākaccāna’s wilderness hut while Mahākaccāna’s wilderness.
ai-sn35:132.1.2_1: Then they walked around the hut, making a dreadful racket,
ai-sn35:132.1.3_0: “These shavelings, fake ascetics, riffraff, black spawn from the feet of our Kinsman, the Lord! They’re honored, respected, esteemed, revered, and venerated by those who pretend to inherit Vedic culture.”
ai-sn35:132.1.4_0: And then Mahākaccāna left his dwelling and said to those brahmin students,
ai-sn35:132.1.6_0: I will speak to you on the teaching.”
ai-sn35:132.1.7_0: When this was said, the students fell silent.
ai-sn35:132.1.8_0: Then Mahākaccāna recited these verses for them.
ai-sn35:132.2.1_0: “The brahmins of old excelled in ethics,
ai-sn35:132.2.3_0: Their sense doors were guarded, well protected,
ai-sn35:132.3.1_0: Those brahmins who remembered the ancient traditions
ai-sn35:132.4.1_0: But these have lost their way. Claiming to recite,
ai-sn35:132.4.2_0: they live out of balance, judging everyone by their clan.
ai-sn35:132.4.3_0: Mastered by anger, they take up many arms,
ai-sn35:132.4.4_0: attacking both the strong and the weak.
ai-sn35:132.5.1_0: All is vain for someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors,
ai-sn35:132.5.2_0: like the wealth a person finds in a dream.
ai-sn35:132.5.4_0: bathing at dawn, the three Vedas,
ai-sn35:132.6.2_0: hymns, precepts and observances, and self-mortification,
ai-sn35:132.6.6_0: are only used to generate profits.
ai-sn35:132.7.4_0: that’s the path to attainment of Brahmā!”
ai-sn35:132.8.1_0: Then those students, offended and upset, went to the brahmin Lohicca and said to him,
ai-sn35:132.8.2_0: “Please, master, you should know this. The ascetic Mahākaccāna condemns and rejects outright the hymns of the brahmins!”
ai-sn35:132.8.3_0: When they said this, Lohicca was offended and upset.
ai-sn35:132.8.5_0: “But it wouldn’t be appropriate for me to abuse or insult the ascetic Mahākaccāna solely because of what I’ve heard from these students.
ai-sn35:132.8.6_0: Why don’t I go and ask him about it?”
ai-sn35:132.9.1_0: Then Lohicca went up to Mahākaccāna, and exchanged greetings with him.
ai-sn35:132.9.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:132.9.2_1: He went to Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
ai-sn35:132.9.3_0: “Master Kaccāna, did several young students of mine come by here collecting firewood?”
ai-sn35:132.9.5_0: “But did you have some discussion with them?”
ai-sn35:132.9.6_0: “Now I did have some discussion with them.”
ai-sn35:132.9.7_0: “But what kind of discussion did you have with them?”
ai-sn35:132.9.8_0: “Indeed I did have some discussion with them:
ai-sn35:132.10.1_0: ‘The brahmins of old excelled in ethics,
ai-sn35:132.10.5_0: that’s the path to attainment of Brahmā!’
ai-sn35:132.11.1_0: That’s how I had some discussion with them.”
ai-sn35:132.12.1_0: “Master Kaccāna spoke of someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors.
ai-sn35:132.12.2_0: How do you define someone who doesn’t guard the sense doors?”
ai-sn35:132.12.3_0: “Brahmin, take someone who sees a sight with their eyes. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart restricted.
ai-sn35:132.12.5_0: When hearing a sound with the ear ...
ai-sn35:132.12.6_0: When smelling an odor with the nose ...
ai-sn35:132.12.7_0: Tasting a flavor with his tongue ...
ai-sn35:132.12.8_0: Feeling a touch with his body ...
ai-sn35:132.12.9_0: When they know a thought with their mind, if it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and a limited heart.
ai-sn35:132.12.11_0: That’s how someone doesn’t guard the sense doors.”
ai-sn35:132.12.13_0: How accurately you’ve explained someone whose sense doors are unguarded!
ai-sn35:132.13.1_0: You also spoke of someone who does guard the sense doors.
ai-sn35:132.13.2_0: How do you define someone who does guard the sense doors?”
ai-sn35:132.13.3_0: “Brahmin, take someone who sees a sight with their eyes. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
ai-sn35:132.13.4_0: And they do understand where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
ai-sn35:132.13.5_0: When hearing a sound with the ear ...
ai-sn35:132.13.6_0: When smelling an odor with the nose ...
ai-sn35:132.13.7_0: Tasting a flavor with his tongue ...
ai-sn35:132.13.8_0: Feeling a touch with his body ...
ai-sn35:132.13.9_0: know a thought with their mind. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
ai-sn35:132.13.10_0: And they do understand where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
ai-sn35:132.13.11_0: That’s how someone guards the sense doors.”
ai-sn35:132.14.2_0: How accurately you’ve explained someone whose sense doors are guarded!
ai-sn35:132.14.4_0: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Kaccāna has made the teaching clear in many ways.
ai-sn35:132.14.4_1: those with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-sn35:132.14.4_2: just so have you made the Teaching clear in many ways.
ai-sn35:132.14.5_0: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-sn35:132.14.6_0: From this day forth, may Master Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
ai-sn35:132.14.7_0: Please come to my family just as you go to the families of the lay followers in Makkarakaṭa.
ai-sn35:132.14.8_0: The brahmin boys and girls there will bow to you, rise in your presence, and give you a seat and water. That will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”
ai-sn35:133.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Udāyī was staying near Kāmaṇḍā in the brahmin Todeyya’s mango grove.
ai-sn35:133.1.2_0: He approached Udāyī and told him what had happened.
ai-sn35:133.1.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:133.1.4_0: Udāyī educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired that student with a Dhamma talk.
ai-sn35:133.1.5_0: Then that student went to the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan and said to her,
ai-sn35:133.1.7_0: The ascetic Udāyī teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.”
ai-sn35:133.2.1_0: “Well then, student, in my name please accept tomorrow’s meal from me.”
ai-sn35:133.2.3_0: “Sir, may Master Udāyī please accept an offering of tomorrow’s meal from my teacher’s wife, the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan.”
ai-sn35:133.2.5_0: Then when the night had passed, Udāyī robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the brahmin lady’s home, and told him of the Verahaccāni clan.
ai-sn35:133.2.5_1: where he sat down on a prepared seat.
ai-sn35:133.2.6_0: Then Udāyī served and satisfied Udāyī with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
ai-sn35:133.2.7_0: When Udāyī had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, she put on a pair of shoes, sat on a high seat, covered her head, and said to him,
ai-sn35:133.2.9_0: “There will be an occasion for that, sister,” he replied, then got up from his seat and left.
ai-sn35:133.3.1_0: For a second time that student went to Udāyī ...
ai-sn35:133.3.2_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:133.3.3_0: Udāyī educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired that student with a Dhamma talk.
ai-sn35:133.3.4_0: And for a second time that student went to the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan ...
ai-sn35:133.3.6_0: The ascetic Udāyī teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.”
ai-sn35:133.4.1_0: She said to him, “You keep praising the ascetic Udāyī like this.
ai-sn35:133.4.2_0: But when I asked him to preach the Dhamma he just said that there would be an occasion for that, and then he got up and left.”
ai-sn35:133.4.3_0: “Madam, that’s because you put on a pair of shoes, sat on a high seat, and covered your head before inviting him to teach.
ai-sn35:133.4.5_0: For the masters respect the teaching.”
ai-sn35:133.4.6_0: “Well then, student, in my name please accept tomorrow’s meal from me.”
ai-sn35:133.4.8_0: “Sir, may Master Udāyī please accept an offering of tomorrow’s meal from my teacher’s wife, the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan.”
ai-sn35:133.5.1_0: Then when the night had passed, Udāyī robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the brahmin lady’s home, and told him of the Verahaccāni clan.
ai-sn35:133.5.1_1: where he sat down on a prepared seat.
ai-sn35:133.5.2_0: Then Udāyī served and satisfied Udāyī with his own hands with a variety of delicious foods.
ai-sn35:133.5.3_0: When Udāyī had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, she took off her shoes, sat on a low seat, uncovered her head, and said to him,
ai-sn35:133.5.4_0: “Sir, when what exists do the perfected ones declare that there is pleasure and pain? When what doesn’t exist do the perfected ones not declare that there is pleasure and pain?”
ai-sn35:133.6.1_0: “Sister, when there’s an eye, the perfected ones declare that there is pleasure and pain. When there’s no eye, the perfected ones don’t declare that there is pleasure and pain.
ai-sn35:133.6.2_0: When there’s an ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:133.6.3_0: mind, the perfected ones declare that there is pleasure and pain. When there’s no mind, the perfected ones don’t declare that there is pleasure and pain.”
ai-sn35:133.7.1_0: When he said this, the brahmin lady said to Udāyī,
ai-sn35:133.7.3_0: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
ai-sn35:133.7.3_1: those with eyes might see what’s there—
ai-sn35:133.7.3_2: even so has this made the Teaching clear in many ways.
ai-sn35:133.7.4_0: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
ai-sn35:133.7.5_0: From this day forth, may Venerable Udāyī remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
ai-sn35:133.7.7_0: The third sub-chapter on householders is finished.
ai-sn35:134.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, where they have a town named Devadaha.
ai-sn35:134.1.3_0: “When it comes to the six fields of contact, mendicants, I don’t say that all mendicants have work to do with diligence, nor do I say that none of them have work to do with diligence.
ai-sn35:134.1.4_0: I say that, when it comes to the six fields of contact, mendicants don’t have work to do with diligence if they are perfected, with defilements ended, having completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and become rightly freed through enlightenment.
ai-sn35:134.1.6_0: They’ve done their work with diligence, and are incapable of negligence.
ai-sn35:134.1.7_0: I say that, when it comes to the six fields of contact, mendicants do have work to do with diligence if they are trainees, who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn35:134.1.9_0: There are sights known by the eye that are pleasant and also those that are unpleasant.
ai-sn35:134.1.11_0: Their energy is roused up and unflagging, their mindfulness is established and lucid, their body is tranquil and undisturbed, and their mind is immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:134.1.12_0: Seeing this fruit of diligence, I say that those mendicants have work to do with diligence when it comes to the six fields of contact. ...
ai-sn35:134.1.13_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are pleasant and also those that are unpleasant.
ai-sn35:134.1.15_0: Their energy is roused up and unflagging, their mindfulness is established and lucid, their body is tranquil and undisturbed, and their mind is immersed in samādhi.
ai-sn35:134.1.16_0: Seeing this fruit of diligence, I say that those mendicants have work to do with diligence when it comes to the six fields of contact.”

ai-sn35:140.1.1_0: “Mendicants, the eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are impermanent.
ai-sn35:140.1.2_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the eye is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:140.1.3_0: Since the eye is produced by what is impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:140.1.5_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the ear ...
ai-sn35:140.1.6_0: Since the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:140.1.8_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the mind is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:140.1.9_0: Since the mind is produced by what is impermanent, how could it be permanent?
ai-sn35:140.1.10_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye ... ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:140.1.10_1: They are repelled by the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:140.1.10_2: They are repelled by the mind, repelled by mental phenomena,
ai-sn35:140.1.11_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:140.1.12_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:141.1.2_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the eye is also suffering.
ai-sn35:141.1.3_0: Since the eye is produced by what is suffering, how could it be happiness?
ai-sn35:141.1.5_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the tongue is also suffering.
ai-sn35:141.1.6_0: Since the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:141.1.8_0: The cause and condition that gives rise to the mind is also suffering.
ai-sn35:141.1.9_0: Since the mind is produced by what is suffering, how could it be happiness?
ai-sn35:141.1.11_0: They understand: ‘... there is no return to any state of existence.’”

ai-sn35:146.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you old action, new action, the cessation of action, and the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
ai-sn35:146.1.2_0: listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:146.1.4_0: The eye is old action. It should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.
ai-sn35:146.1.6_0: mind is old action. It should be seen as produced by choices and intentions, as something to be felt.
ai-sn35:146.1.9_0: Whatever deeds do you act by way of body, speech, or mind,
ai-sn35:146.1.11_0: And what is the cessation of deeds?
ai-sn35:146.1.12_0: When you experience freedom due to the cessation of deeds by body, speech, and mind.
ai-sn35:146.1.13_0: This is called the cessation of deeds.
ai-sn35:146.1.14_0: And what’s the practice that leads to the cessation of action?
ai-sn35:146.1.15_0: It’s just this noble eightfold path,
ai-sn35:146.1.16_0: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-sn35:146.1.17_0: This is called the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
ai-sn35:146.1.18_0: So, mendicants, I’ve taught you old action, new action, the cessation of action, and the practice that leads to the cessation of action.
ai-sn35:146.1.19_0: Out of compassion, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
ai-sn35:146.1.20_0: Here, mendicants, are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts.
ai-sn35:146.1.20_1: Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent!
ai-sn35:146.1.20_3: Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”

ai-sn35:147.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you the practice that leads to extinguishment.
ai-sn35:147.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak. ...
ai-sn35:147.1.3_0: And what is the practice that leads to extinguishment?
ai-sn35:147.1.4_0: It’s when a mendicant sees that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent.
ai-sn35:147.1.4_1: And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:147.1.5_0: They see that the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:147.1.6_0: mind, thoughts, mind-consciousness, and mind contact are impermanent. And they see that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:147.1.7_0: This is the way of practice suitable for attaining extinguishment.”
ai-sn35:148.0.3_0: Having cut off the stain of stinginess, freely pain, and distress.

ai-sn35:151.1.1_0: “Mendicants, this spiritual life is lived without a resident student and without a teaching master.
ai-sn35:151.1.2_0: A mendicant who lives with a resident student and a teaching master lives in suffering and discomfort.
ai-sn35:151.1.3_0: A mendicant who lives without a resident student and a teaching master lives in happiness and comfort.
ai-sn35:151.1.4_0: And how does a mendicant who lives with a resident student and a teaching master live in suffering and discomfort?
ai-sn35:151.1.5_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.
ai-sn35:151.1.6_0: He stayed in his hole, bad, unskillful qualities on the earth.
ai-sn35:151.1.7_0: This being so, one who lives in balanced.
ai-sn35:151.1.8_0: They are a bear, bad, unskillful qualities.
ai-sn35:151.1.9_0: they’re said to have a teaching master.

ai-sn35:151.2.3_0: This being so, one who lives in balanced.
ai-sn35:151.2.4_0: They are bearded, unskillful qualities, and they’re called ‘one who frequents’.
ai-sn35:151.3.1_0: knows a thought with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts prone to fetters.

ai-sn35:151.3.6_0: That’s how a mendicant who lives with a resident student and a teaching master lives in suffering and discomfort.
ai-sn35:151.4.1_0: And how does a mendicant who lives without a resident student and a teaching master live in happiness and comfort?

ai-sn35:153.1.1_0: “Mendicants, is there a method—apart from faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment? That is:
ai-sn35:153.1.2_0: ‘I understand: “Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.”’”
ai-sn35:153.1.3_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-sn35:153.1.3_1: He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-sn35:153.1.3_2: Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-sn35:153.1.4_0: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn35:153.1.7_0: “There is a method—apart from faith, preference, oral tradition, reasoned contemplation, or acceptance of a view after consideration—that a mendicant can rely on to declare their enlightenment. That is:

ai-sn35:153.2.3_0: When there is no greed, hate, and delusion in them, they understand that.
ai-sn35:153.2.4_1: When there is no greed, hate, and delusion in them, they understand that.

ai-sn35:154.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and said:
ai-sn35:154.1.3_0: How is someone who is accomplished regarding the faculties defined?”
ai-sn35:154.2.1_0: “Mendicant, if someone meditates observing rise and fall in the eye faculty, they grow disillusioned with the eye faculty.
ai-sn35:154.2.2_0: If they meditate observing rise and fall in the ear faculty ... nose faculty ... tongue faculty ... body faculty ...
ai-sn35:154.2.3_0: mind faculty, they grow disillusioned with the faculties of the mind faculty.
ai-sn35:154.2.4_0: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. ... When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
ai-sn35:154.2.5_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-sn35:154.2.6_0: This is how someone who is accomplished regarding the faculties is defined.”
ai-sn35:155.0.3_0: Love and asks those Dhamma speaker:
ai-sn35:155.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and said:
ai-sn35:155.1.3_0: How is a Dhamma speaker defined?”
ai-sn35:155.2.1_0: “If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.
ai-sn35:155.2.2_0: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
ai-sn35:155.2.3_0: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the eye, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.
ai-sn35:155.2.4_0: If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment with the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:155.2.5_0: mind, for its fading away and cessation, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.
ai-sn35:155.2.6_0: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the mind, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
ai-sn35:155.2.7_0: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding the mind, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.”

ai-sn35:155.3.5_0: The third sub-chapter on the six sense fields is finished.

ai-sn35:160.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Mango Grove of Jīvaka Komārabhacca.

ai-sn35:160.1.7_0: It becomes truly clear that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent. And it also becomes truly clear that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is impermanent. ...
ai-sn35:160.1.8_0: It becomes truly clear that the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...

ai-sn35:160.1.10_0: And the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:160.1.12_0: For a mendicant with immersion, things become truly clear.”
ai-sn35:161.0.3_0: Practice absorption, Jīvaka, the disappearance of the Monastic Code.
ai-sn35:161.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Mango Grove of Jīvaka Komārabhacca.
ai-sn35:161.1.2_0: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
ai-sn35:161.1.4_0: For a mendicant who meditates in retreat, things become truly clear.
ai-sn35:161.1.5_0: And what things do they truly understand?
ai-sn35:161.1.6_0: It becomes truly clear that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent. And it also becomes truly clear that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is impermanent. ...
ai-sn35:161.1.10_0: And the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:161.1.12_0: For a mendicant who meditates in retreat, things become truly clear.”

ai-sn35:165.1.1_0: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha ... and said:
ai-sn35:165.1.3_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that wrong view is given up?”
ai-sn35:165.2.1_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as impermanent, wrong view is given up. ...
ai-sn35:165.2.4_0: Knowing and seeing eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as impermanent, wrong view is given up. ...
ai-sn35:165.2.5_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as impermanent, wrong view is given up.
ai-sn35:165.2.6_0: This is how to know and see so that wrong view is given up.”
ai-sn35:166.0.3_0: From this day forth, identity view.
ai-sn35:166.1.3_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that identity view is given up?”
ai-sn35:166.1.4_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as suffering, identity view is given up. ...
ai-sn35:166.1.6_0: Knowing and seeing eye consciousness, identity view is given up.
ai-sn35:166.1.7_0: Knowing and seeing suffering as suffering, identity view ...
ai-sn35:166.1.8_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as suffering, identity view is given up.
ai-sn35:166.1.9_0: This is how to know and see so that identity view is given up.”
ai-sn35:167.1.3_0: “Sir, how does one know and see so that view of self is given up?”
ai-sn35:167.1.4_0: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as not-self, view of self is given up. ...
ai-sn35:167.1.5_0: Knowing and seeing sights, self as not-self, and view of self is given up.
ai-sn35:167.1.6_0: Knowing and seeing eye consciousness, and eye contact as not-self, view of self is given up.
ai-sn35:167.1.7_0: Knowing and seeing as not-self, eye contact as self, and view of self is given up.
ai-sn35:167.1.8_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact as not-self, view of self is given up. ...
ai-sn35:167.1.9_0: Knowing and seeing the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:167.1.10_0: Knowing and seeing the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact as not-self, view of self is given up.
ai-sn35:167.1.11_0: By directly knowing and completely understanding thoughts ...
ai-sn35:167.1.14_0: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as not-self, view of self is given up.”

ai-sn35:186.1.3_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
