ai-sn35:228.1.1_0: “‘An uneducated ordinary person speaks of the ocean.’
ai-sn35:228.1.2_0: or the training of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:228.1.3_0: That great water, a transmission of water.
ai-sn35:228.1.4_0: For a person, the eye is an ocean,
ai-sn35:228.1.5_0: and its currents are made of sights.
ai-sn35:228.2.1_0: Someone who can withstand those currents is said to have crossed over the ocean of the eye, with its waves and whirlpools, its sharks and monsters.
ai-sn35:228.2.2_0: Crossed over, the brahmin stands on the far shore.
ai-sn35:228.2.3_0: For a person, the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:228.2.5_0: Someone who can withstand those currents is said to have crossed over the ocean of the ear, the nose, tongue, body, and mind with its waves and whirlpools, its sharks and monsters.
ai-sn35:228.2.6_0: Crossed over, the brahmin stands on the far shore.
ai-sn35:228.2.8_0: and its currents are made of thoughts.
ai-sn35:228.2.9_0: Someone who can withstand those currents is said to have crossed over the ocean of the mind, with its waves and whirlpools, its sharks and monsters.
ai-sn35:228.2.10_0: Crossed over, the brahmin stands on the far shore.”
ai-sn35:228.2.11_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-sn35:228.3.1_0: “A knowledge master who’s crossed the ocean so hard to cross,
ai-sn35:228.3.2_0: with its sharks and monsters, its waves, whirlpools, and dangers;
ai-sn35:228.3.3_0: they’ve completed the spiritual journey, and gone to the end of the world,
ai-sn35:228.3.4_0: and gone to the end of the world, is called ‘one who has gone beyond’.”
ai-sn35:228.3.5_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn35:229.1.1_0: “‘An uneducated ordinary person speaks of the ocean.’
ai-sn35:229.1.2_0: or the training of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:229.1.3_0: That great water, a transmission of water.
ai-sn35:229.1.4_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:229.1.5_0: This is called the ocean of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:229.1.6_0: And it’s here that this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—is for the most part sunk. It’s become tangled like string, knotted like a ball of thread, and matted like rushes and reeds, and it doesn’t escape the places of loss, the bad places, the underworld, transmigration.
ai-sn35:229.2.1_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:229.2.1_1: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:229.2.2_0: This is called the ocean of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:229.2.3_0: And it’s here that this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—is for the most part sunk. It’s become tangled like string, knotted like a ball of thread, and matted like rushes and reeds, and it doesn’t escape the places of loss, the bad places, the underworld, transmigration.
ai-sn35:229.3.3_0: have crossed the ocean so hard to cross,
ai-sn35:229.3.4_0: with its sharks and monsters, its waves and dangers.
ai-sn35:229.4.1_0: They’ve escaped their chains, given up death, and have no attachments.
ai-sn35:229.4.2_0: Painful, the suffering that leads to future lives.
ai-sn35:229.4.4_0: and they’ve confounded the King of Death, I say.”
ai-sn35:230.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose a fisherman was to cast a baited hook into a deep lake.
ai-sn35:230.1.2_0: and someone was to throw them out.
ai-sn35:230.1.3_0: And so the fish that swallowed the hook would meet with tragedy and disaster, and the fisherman can do what he wants with it.
ai-sn35:230.2.1_0: In the same way, there are these six hooks in the world that mean tragedy and slaughter for living creatures.
ai-sn35:230.2.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by six?
ai-sn35:230.2.3_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:230.2.4_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:230.2.5_0: they’re called a mendicant who has swallowed Māra’s hook. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can do what he wants with them.
ai-sn35:230.2.6_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:230.3.1_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:230.3.2_0: If a mendicant approves, welcomes, and keep clinging to them,
ai-sn35:230.3.3_0: they’re called a mendicant who has swallowed Māra’s hook. They’ve met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One can do what he wants with them.
ai-sn35:230.4.1_0: There are sights known by the eye that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:230.4.2_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook.
ai-sn35:230.4.2_1: They’ve broken the hook, destroyed it. They haven’t met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One cannot do what he wants with them.
ai-sn35:230.5.1_0: There are sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:230.5.2_0: There are thoughts known by the mind that are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
ai-sn35:230.5.3_0: If a mendicant doesn’t approve, welcome, and keep clinging to them, they’re called a mendicant who hasn’t swallowed Māra’s hook. They’ve broken the hook, destroyed it. They haven’t met with tragedy and disaster, and the Wicked One cannot do what he wants with them.”
ai-sn35:231.0.3_0: 231. The Simile of the Latex-Producing Tree
ai-sn35:231.1.1_0: “Mendicants, take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, still has greed, hate, and delusion, and has not given them up. If even trivial sights come into their range of vision they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.
ai-sn35:231.1.3_0: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.
ai-sn35:231.2.1_0: When it comes to sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:231.3.1_0: thoughts known by the mind, they have greed, hate, and delusion left, and have not given them up. If even trivial thoughts come into the range of the mind they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.
ai-sn35:231.3.3_0: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.
ai-sn35:231.4.1_0: Suppose there was a latex-producing tree—such as a bodhi, a banyan, a wavy leaf fig, or a cluster fig—that’s a tender young sapling.
ai-sn35:231.4.2_0: Then along comes a person with a sharp point, which gives rise to milk.”
ai-sn35:231.5.1_0: “In the same way, take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, still has greed, hate, and delusion, and has not given them up. If even trivial sights come into their range of vision they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.
ai-sn35:231.5.3_0: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.
ai-sn35:231.6.1_0: When it comes to sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:231.7.1_0: thoughts known by the mind, they have greed, hate, and delusion left, and have not given them up. If even trivial thoughts come into the range of the mind they overcome their mind, let alone those that are compelling.
ai-sn35:231.7.3_0: Because they still have greed, hate, and delusion, and have not given them up.
ai-sn35:231.8.1_0: Take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, has no greed, hate, and delusion left, and has given them up. If even compelling sights come into their range of vision they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.
ai-sn35:231.8.3_0: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.
ai-sn35:231.9.1_0: Any monk or nun who has desire or greed or hate or delusion or repulsion come up for sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:231.9.1_1: thoughts known by the mind, they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up. If even compelling thoughts come into the range of the mind they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.
ai-sn35:231.9.3_0: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.
ai-sn35:231.9.4_0: Suppose there was a latex-producing tree—such as a bodhi, a banyan, a wavy leaf fig, or a cluster fig—that’s dried up, withered, and decrepit.
ai-sn35:231.9.5_0: Then along comes a person with a sharp point, which gives rise to milk.”
ai-sn35:231.9.8_0: Because it has no latex left.”
ai-sn35:231.10.1_0: “In the same way, take any monk or nun who, when it comes to sights known by the eye, has no greed, hate, and delusion left, and has given them up. If even compelling sights come into their range of vision they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.
ai-sn35:231.10.3_0: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.
ai-sn35:231.11.1_0: When it comes to sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:231.12.1_0: thoughts known by the mind, they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up. If even compelling thoughts come into the range of the mind they don’t overcome their mind, let alone those that are trivial.
ai-sn35:231.12.3_0: Because they have no greed, hate, and delusion left, and have given them up.”
ai-sn35:232.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana. ...
ai-sn35:232.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta,
ai-sn35:232.1.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:232.1.3_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Sāriputta:
ai-sn35:232.2.1_0: “Reverend Sāriputta, which is it? Is the eye the fetter of sights, or are sights the fetter of the eye?
ai-sn35:232.2.3_0: mind is the fetter of thoughts, and thoughts prone to being fettered?”
ai-sn35:232.3.1_0: “Reverend Koṭṭhita, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.
ai-sn35:232.3.2_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:232.3.4_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:232.3.5_0: mind is not the fetter of thoughts, nor are thoughts the fetter of the mind.
ai-sn35:232.3.6_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:232.4.1_0: Suppose there was a black ox and a white ox yoked by a single harness or yoke.
ai-sn35:232.4.2_0: Suppose someone were to say this:
ai-sn35:232.4.3_0: the white ox, the yoke of the white ox, the white ox, and the yoke of the black ox.”
ai-sn35:232.4.5_0: The black ox is not the yoke of the white ox, nor is the white ox the yoke of the black ox.
ai-sn35:232.4.6_0: The yoke there is the single harness or yoke that they’re yoked by.”
ai-sn35:232.5.1_0: “In the same way, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.
ai-sn35:232.5.2_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:232.5.4_0: mind is not the fetter of thoughts, nor are thoughts the fetter of the mind.
ai-sn35:232.5.5_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:232.6.1_0: If the eye were the fetter of sights, or if sights were the fetter of the eye, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering would not be found.
ai-sn35:232.6.2_0: However, since this is not the case, but
ai-sn35:232.6.3_0: the fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering is found.
ai-sn35:232.7.1_0: If the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:232.7.2_0: However, since this is not the case, but
ai-sn35:232.7.2_1: the fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering is found.
ai-sn35:232.8.1_0: mind were the fetter of thoughts, or if thoughts were the fetter of the mind, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering would not be found.
ai-sn35:232.8.2_0: However, since this is not the case, but
ai-sn35:232.8.3_0: the fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them, this living of the spiritual life for the complete ending of suffering is found.
ai-sn35:232.9.1_0: This too is a way to understand how this is so.
ai-sn35:232.9.2_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:232.9.4_0: mind is not the fetter of thoughts, nor are thoughts the fetter of the mind.
ai-sn35:232.9.5_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:232.10.2_0: with which he sees a sight.
ai-sn35:232.10.3_0: and there is no desire for the Buddha.
ai-sn35:232.10.4_0: The Buddha well freed in mind.
ai-sn35:232.10.6_0: He hears sound with the ear.
ai-sn35:232.10.7_0: and there is no desire for the Buddha.
ai-sn35:232.10.8_0: The Buddha well freed in mind.
ai-sn35:232.10.10_0: the Buddha bathed with a odor of the nose.
ai-sn35:232.10.11_0: and there is no desire for the Buddha.
ai-sn35:232.10.12_0: The Buddha well freed in mind.
ai-sn35:232.10.15_0: and there is no desire for the Buddha.
ai-sn35:232.10.16_0: The Buddha well freed in mind.
ai-sn35:232.10.18_0: the Buddha touched by the body.
ai-sn35:232.10.19_0: and there is no desire for the Buddha.
ai-sn35:232.10.20_0: The Buddha well freed in mind.
ai-sn35:232.10.23_0: and there is no desire for the Buddha.
ai-sn35:232.10.24_0: The Buddha well freed in mind.
ai-sn35:232.11.1_0: This too is a way to understand how the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.
ai-sn35:232.11.2_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:232.11.6_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:232.11.8_0: mind is not the fetter of thoughts, nor are thoughts the fetter of the mind.
ai-sn35:232.11.9_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.”
ai-sn35:233.1.1_0: At one time the venerables Ānanda and Kāmabhū were staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
ai-sn35:233.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Kāmabhū came out of retreat, went to Venerable Ānanda, and
ai-sn35:233.1.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:233.2.1_0: “Reverend Ānanda, when the eye is the fetter of sights, or are sights the fetter of the eye?
ai-sn35:233.2.3_0: mind is the fetter of thoughts, and thoughts prone to being fettered?”
ai-sn35:233.3.1_0: “Reverend Kāmabhū, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.
ai-sn35:233.3.2_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:233.3.4_0: mind is not the fetter of thoughts, nor are thoughts the fetter of the mind.
ai-sn35:233.3.5_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.
ai-sn35:233.4.1_0: Suppose there was a black ox and a white ox yoked by a single harness or yoke.
ai-sn35:233.4.2_0: Suppose someone were to say this:
ai-sn35:233.4.3_0: the white ox, the yoke of the white ox, the white ox, and the yoke of the black ox.”
ai-sn35:233.4.5_0: The black ox is not the yoke of the white ox, nor is the white ox the yoke of the black ox.
ai-sn35:233.4.6_0: The yoke there is the single harness or yoke that they’re yoked by.”
ai-sn35:233.4.7_0: “In the same way, the eye is not the fetter of sights, nor are sights the fetter of the eye.
ai-sn35:233.4.9_0: mind is not the fetter of thoughts, nor are thoughts the fetter of the mind.
ai-sn35:233.4.10_0: The fetter there is the desire and greed that arises from the pair of them.”
ai-sn35:234.1.1_0: At one time the venerables Ānanda and Udāyī were staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
ai-sn35:234.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Udāyī came out of retreat, went to Venerable Ānanda, and
ai-sn35:234.1.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn35:234.1.3_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Ānanda:
ai-sn35:234.2.1_0: “Reverend Ānanda, the Buddha has explained, opened, and illuminated in many ways how this body is not-self.
ai-sn35:234.3.1_0: “Just now, reverend Udāyī, this body has been explained by the Buddha in many ways how this body is not-self.
ai-sn35:234.4.1_0: Does eye consciousness arise dependent on the eye and sights?”
ai-sn35:234.4.3_0: “If the cause and condition that gives rise to eye consciousness were to totally and utterly cease without anything left over,
ai-sn35:234.4.3_1: That eye consciousness still is found?”
ai-sn35:234.4.5_0: “In this way, too, it can be understood how the Buddha has explained.
ai-sn35:234.5.3_0: “If the cause and condition that gives rise to tongue consciousness were to totally and utterly cease without anything left over, would consciousness still be found?”
ai-sn35:234.5.5_0: “In this way, too, it can be understood how the Buddha has explained.
ai-sn35:234.6.1_0: mind consciousness arise dependent on the mind and thoughts?”
ai-sn35:234.6.3_0: “If the cause and condition that gives rise to mind consciousness were to totally and utterly cease without anything left over, would mind consciousness still be found?”
ai-sn35:234.6.5_0: “In this way, too, it can be understood how the Buddha has explained.
ai-sn35:234.7.1_0: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood.
ai-sn35:234.7.1_1: There they’d see a big banana tree, straight and young and grown free of defects.
ai-sn35:234.7.1_2: There they’d see a big banana tree,
ai-sn35:234.7.1_5: They’d cut it down at the base, cut off the root, cut off the top, and unroll the coiled sheaths. But they wouldn’t even find sapwood, much less heartwood.
ai-sn35:234.7.2_0: In the same way, a mendicant sees these six fields of contact as neither self nor belonging to self.
ai-sn35:234.7.3_0: So seeing, they don’t grasp anything in the world.
ai-sn35:234.7.4_0: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
ai-sn35:234.7.5_0: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
ai-sn35:235.1.1_0: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition of the teaching on burning.
ai-sn35:235.1.2_0: Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.
ai-sn35:235.1.3_0: And what is the exposition of the teaching on burning?
ai-sn35:235.1.4_0: You’d be better off mutilating your eye faculty with a red-hot iron nail, burning, blazing and glowing, than getting caught up in the features by way of the details in sights known by the eye.
ai-sn35:235.1.5_0: For if you die at a time when your consciousness is still tied to gratification in the features or details, it’s possible you’ll go to one of two destinations:
ai-sn35:235.1.7_0: I speak having seen this drawback.
ai-sn35:235.2.1_0: You’d be better off mutilating your ear faculty with a sharp iron spike ...
ai-sn35:235.2.2_0: For if you die at a time when your consciousness is still tied to gratification in the features or details, it’s possible you’ll go to one of two destinations:
ai-sn35:235.2.4_0: I speak having seen this drawback.
ai-sn35:235.3.1_0: You’d be better off mutilating your nose faculty with a sharp nail cutter ...
ai-sn35:235.3.2_0: As long as consciousness remains, it would remain involved with features and details.
ai-sn35:235.3.3_0: For it’s possible that two destinations:
ai-sn35:235.3.5_0: I speak having seen this drawback.
ai-sn35:235.4.1_0: You’d be better off mutilating your tongue faculty with a sharp razor ...
ai-sn35:235.4.2_0: As long as consciousness remains, it would remain involved with features and details.
ai-sn35:235.4.3_0: For it’s possible that two destinations:
ai-sn35:235.4.5_0: I speak having seen this drawback.
ai-sn35:235.5.1_0: You’d be better off mutilating your body faculty with a sharp spear, burning, blazing and glowing, than getting caught up in the features by way of the details in touches known by the body.
ai-sn35:235.5.2_0: As long as consciousness remains, it would remain involved with features and details.
ai-sn35:235.5.3_0: For it’s possible that two destinations:
ai-sn35:235.5.5_0: I speak having seen this drawback.
ai-sn35:235.6.2_0: For I say that sleep is useless, fruitless, and unconsciousness for the living. But while you’re asleep you won’t fall under the sway of such thoughts that would make you create a schism in the Saṅgha.
ai-sn35:235.6.3_0: I speak having seen this drawback.
ai-sn35:235.7.1_0: A noble disciple reflects on this:
ai-sn35:235.7.2_0: ‘Forget mutilating the eye faculty with a red-hot iron nail, burning, blazing and glowing!
ai-sn35:235.7.4_0: the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:235.8.1_0: Forget mutilating the ear faculty with a sharp iron spike, burning, blazing and glowing!
ai-sn35:235.8.3_0: the ear, sounds, ear consciousness, and ear contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by ear contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:235.9.1_0: Forget mutilating the nose faculty with a sharp nail cutter, burning, blazing and glowing!
ai-sn35:235.9.3_0: the nose, smells, nose consciousness, and nose contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by nose contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:235.10.1_0: Forget mutilating the tongue faculty with a sharp razor, burning, blazing and glowing!
ai-sn35:235.10.3_0: the tongue, tastes, tongue consciousness, and tongue contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by tongue contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:235.11.1_0: Forget mutilating the body faculty with a sharp spear, burning, blazing and glowing!
ai-sn35:235.11.3_0: the body, touches, body consciousness, and body contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by body contact is also impermanent.
ai-sn35:235.12.3_0: the mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact are impermanent. And the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact is also impermanent.”
ai-sn35:235.13.1_0: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact. And they grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by eye contact.
ai-sn35:235.13.2_0: They grow disillusioned with the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact.
ai-sn35:235.13.3_0: Being repelled, they become desireless. Because they are desireless, they are freed. When they are freed, they know they are freed.
ai-sn35:235.13.4_0: He understands: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
ai-sn35:235.13.5_0: This is the exposition of the teaching on burning.”
ai-sn35:236.0.3_0: Fetting Herew out the previous ones’s porridge!
ai-sn35:236.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when there are hands, picking up and putting down are found.
ai-sn35:236.1.2_0: When there are feet, coming and going are found.
ai-sn35:236.1.3_0: When there are joints, contracting and extending are found.
ai-sn35:236.1.4_0: When there’s a belly, hunger and thirst are found.
ai-sn35:236.1.5_0: In the same way, when there’s an eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind arises.
ai-sn35:236.1.6_0: When there’s an ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:236.1.7_0: mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact are suffering.
ai-sn35:236.2.1_0: When there are no hands, picking up and putting down aren’t found.
ai-sn35:236.2.2_0: When there are no feet, coming and going aren’t found.
ai-sn35:236.2.3_0: When there are no joints, contracting and extending aren’t found.
ai-sn35:236.2.4_0: When there’s no belly, hunger and thirst aren’t found.
ai-sn35:236.2.5_0: In the same way, there’s no eye, no pleasure or pain arise in oneself.
ai-sn35:237.0.3_0: His hands and feet cling gracefully.
ai-sn35:237.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when there are hands, there’s picking up and putting down.
ai-sn35:237.1.2_0: When there are feet, there’s coming and going.
ai-sn35:237.1.3_0: When there are joints, there’s contracting and extending.
ai-sn35:237.1.4_0: When there’s a belly, there’s a hunger and thirst.
ai-sn35:237.1.5_0: In the same way, when there’s an eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind arises.
ai-sn35:237.1.6_0: When there’s an ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:237.1.7_0: mind, thoughts, mind consciousness, and mind contact are suffering.
ai-sn35:237.2.1_0: When there are no hands, there’s no picking up and putting down.
ai-sn35:237.2.2_0: When there are no feet, there’s no coming and going.
ai-sn35:237.2.3_0: When there are no joints, there’s no contracting and extending.
ai-sn35:237.2.4_0: When there’s no belly, there’s no hunger and thirst.
ai-sn35:237.2.5_0: In the same way, there’s no eye, no pleasure or pain arise in oneself.
ai-sn35:237.2.9_0: The third sub-chapter on the ocean is finished.
ai-sn35:237.3.4_0: and the eighth day are burning,
ai-sn35:238.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose there were four lethal poisonous vipers.
ai-sn35:238.1.2_0: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
ai-sn35:238.1.4_0: ‘Mister, here are four lethal poisonous vipers. They must be periodically picked up, washed, fed, and put to sleep.
ai-sn35:238.1.5_0: But when one or other of these four poisonous vipers gets angry with you, you’ll meet with death or deadly pain.
ai-sn35:238.1.6_0: So, mister, you should do what you must!’
ai-sn35:238.2.1_0: Then that man, terrified of those four poisonous vipers, would flee this way or that.
ai-sn35:238.2.3_0: ‘Mister, there are five deadly enemies chasing you, thinking: “When we catch sight of him, we’ll murder him right there!”
ai-sn35:238.2.4_0: So, mister, you should do what you must!’
ai-sn35:238.3.1_0: Then that man, terrified of those four poisonous vipers and those five deadly enemies, would flee this way or that.
ai-sn35:238.3.3_0: ‘Mister, there’s a sixth hidden killer chasing you with a drawn sword, thinking: “When I catch sight of him, I’ll chop off his head right there!”
ai-sn35:238.3.4_0: So, mister, you should do what you must!’
ai-sn35:238.4.1_0: Then that man, terrified of those four poisonous vipers and those five deadly enemies and the hidden killer, would flee this way or that.
ai-sn35:238.4.3_0: But whatever house he enters is vacant, deserted, and empty.
ai-sn35:238.4.4_0: And whatever vessel he touches is vacant, hollow, and empty.
ai-sn35:238.4.6_0: ‘Mister, there are bandits who raid villages, and they’re striking now.
ai-sn35:238.4.7_0: So, mister, you should do what you must!’
ai-sn35:238.5.1_0: Then that man, terrified of those four poisonous vipers and those five deadly enemies and the hidden killer and the bandits, would flee this way or that.
ai-sn35:238.5.2_0: He’d see a large deluge, whose near shore is dubious and perilous, while the far shore is a sanctuary free of peril.
ai-sn35:238.5.3_0: But there was no ferryboat or bridge for crossing over.
ai-sn35:238.5.5_0: ‘This big banana tree is the near shore, and not far shore. There’s no danger of sharks, a sanctuary free of peril from the near shore or a sanctuary free of peril.
ai-sn35:238.5.6_0: ‘Why don’t I gather grass, sticks, branches, and leaves and make a raft? Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I can safely reach the far shore.’
ai-sn35:238.6.1_0: And so that man did exactly that. Having crossed over and gone beyond, the brahmin stands on the far shore.
ai-sn35:238.7.1_0: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
ai-sn35:238.7.3_0: ‘Four lethal poisonous vipers’ is a term for the four primary elements:
ai-sn35:238.8.1_0: ‘Five deadly enemies’ is a term for the five grasping aggregates, that is:
ai-sn35:238.8.2_0: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
ai-sn35:238.9.1_0: ‘The sixth hidden killer with a drawn sword’ is a term for relishing and greed.
ai-sn35:238.10.1_0: ‘Empty village’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.
ai-sn35:238.10.2_0: If an astute, competent, clever person investigates this in relation to the eye, it appears vacant, hollow, and empty.
ai-sn35:238.10.3_0: If an astute, competent, clever person investigates this in relation to the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:238.10.4_0: mind, it appears vacant, hollow, and empty.
ai-sn35:238.11.1_0: ‘Bandits who raid villages’ is a term for the six exterior sense fields.
ai-sn35:238.11.2_0: The eye is struck by both pleasant and unpleasant sights.
ai-sn35:238.11.7_0: mind by both pleasant and unpleasant thoughts.
ai-sn35:238.12.1_0: ‘Large deluge’ is a term for the four floods:
ai-sn35:238.12.2_0: the floods of sensual pleasures, desire to be reborn, views, and ignorance.
ai-sn35:238.13.1_0: ‘The near shore that’s dubious and perilous’ is a term for identity.
ai-sn35:238.14.1_0: ‘The far shore, a sanctuary free of peril’ is a term for extinguishment.
ai-sn35:238.15.1_0: ‘The raft’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is:
ai-sn35:238.15.2_0: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-sn35:238.16.1_0: ‘Paddling with hands and feet’ is a term for being energetic.
ai-sn35:238.17.1_0: ‘Crossed over, gone beyond, the brahmin stands on the shore’ is a term for a perfected one.”
ai-sn35:238.17.2_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn35:239.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when a mendicant has three qualities they’re full of joy and happiness in the present life, and they have laid the groundwork for ending the defilements.
ai-sn35:239.1.3_0: They guard the sense doors, eat in moderation, and are committed to wakefulness.
ai-sn35:239.2.1_0: And how does a mendicant guard the sense doors?
ai-sn35:239.2.2_0: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:239.2.3_0: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming.
ai-sn35:239.2.3_1: For this reason, they practice restraint,
ai-sn35:239.2.3_3: For the restraint of the eye, he is restraint of the faculty.
ai-sn35:239.2.4_0: When hearing a sound with the ear ...
ai-sn35:239.2.5_0: When smelling an odor with the nose ...
ai-sn35:239.2.6_0: Tasting a flavor with his tongue ...
ai-sn35:239.2.7_0: Feeling a touch with his body ...
ai-sn35:239.2.8_0: Knowing a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:239.2.9_0: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming.
ai-sn35:239.2.9_1: they protect the faculties of the mind.
ai-sn35:239.2.10_0: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
ai-sn35:239.2.10_1: Then a deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.
ai-sn35:239.2.11_0: In the same way, a mendicant trains to protect, control, tame, and pacify these six senses.
ai-sn35:239.2.12_0: That’s how a mendicant guards the sense doors.
ai-sn35:239.3.1_0: And how does a mendicant eat in moderation?
ai-sn35:239.3.2_0: Take a mendicant who reflects properly on the food that they eat:
ai-sn35:239.3.3_0: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will live blamelessly and at ease.’
ai-sn35:239.3.4_0: Suppose a person was to carry a load of sal tree all over this long time, but the wind rustled as far as the rubbish heaps.
ai-sn35:239.3.5_0: In the same way, a mendicant reflects properly on the food that they eat:
ai-sn35:239.3.6_0: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will live blamelessly and at ease.’
ai-sn35:239.3.7_0: That’s how a mendicant eats in moderation.
ai-sn35:239.4.1_0: And how is a mendicant committed to wakefulness?
ai-sn35:239.4.2_0: It’s when a mendicant practices walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying their mind from obstacles.
ai-sn35:239.4.3_0: In the evening, he continues to practice walking and sitting meditation.
ai-sn35:239.4.4_0: In the middle of the night, he lies down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
ai-sn35:239.4.5_0: In the last part of the night, he gets up and continues to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying his mind from obstacles.
ai-sn35:239.4.6_0: This is how a mendicant is committed to wakefulness.
ai-sn35:239.4.7_0: When a mendicant has these three qualities they’re full of joy and happiness in the present life, and they have laid the groundwork for ending the defilements.”
ai-sn35:240.1.1_0: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a tortoise was grazing along the bank of a river in the afternoon.
ai-sn35:240.1.2_0: At the same time, a jackal was also hunting along the river bank.
ai-sn35:240.1.3_0: The tortoise saw the jackal off in the distance hunting,
ai-sn35:240.1.4_0: so it drew its limbs and neck inside its shell, and kept passive and silent.
ai-sn35:240.1.5_0: But the jackal also saw the tortoise off in the distance grazing.
ai-sn35:240.1.6_0: So it went up to the tortoise and waiting nearby, thinking,
ai-sn35:240.1.7_0: ‘When that tortoise sticks one or other of its limbs or neck out from its shell, I’ll grab it right there, rip it out, and eat it!’
ai-sn35:240.1.8_0: But when that tortoise didn’t stick one or other of its limbs or neck out from its shell, the jackal left disappointed, since it couldn’t find a vulnerability.
ai-sn35:240.2.1_0: In the same way, Māra the Wicked is always waiting nearby, thinking:
ai-sn35:240.2.2_0: ‘Hopefully I can find a vulnerability in the eye,
ai-sn35:240.2.4_0: may I get a little baby boy!’
ai-sn35:240.2.5_0: That’s why you should live with sense doors guarded.
ai-sn35:240.2.6_0: When you see a sight with your eyes, don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:240.2.7_0: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
ai-sn35:240.2.8_0: When hearing a sound with the ear ...
ai-sn35:240.2.9_0: When smelling an odor with the nose ...
ai-sn35:240.2.10_0: Tasting a flavor with his tongue ...
ai-sn35:240.2.11_0: Feeling a touch with his body ...
ai-sn35:240.2.12_0: When you know a thought with your mind, don’t get caught up in the features and details.
ai-sn35:240.2.13_0: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
ai-sn35:240.2.14_0: When you live with your sense doors restrained, Māra will leave you disappointed, since he can’t find a vulnerability,
ai-sn35:240.3.1_0: Like a fish caught in the net,
ai-sn35:240.3.4_0: someone who’s extinguished wouldn’t blame anyone.”
ai-sn35:241.0.3_0: From the bank of the river Sappinikā,
ai-sn35:241.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi on the bank of the Ganges river.
ai-sn35:241.1.4_0: “Mendicants, do you see that large tree trunk?”
ai-sn35:241.1.6_0: “Mendicants, assume that that tree trunk doesn’t collide with the near shore or the far shore, or sink in the middle, or get stranded on high ground. And assume that it doesn’t get taken by humans or non-humans or caught up in a whirlpool, and that it doesn’t rot away.
ai-sn35:241.1.7_0: In that case, that tree trunk will slant, slope, and incline towards the ocean.
ai-sn35:241.1.9_0: Because the current of the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines towards the ocean.
ai-sn35:241.2.1_0: In the same way, assume that you don’t collide with the near shore or the far shore, or sink in the middle, or get stranded on high ground. And assume that you don’t get taken by humans or non-humans or caught up in a whirlpool, and that you don’t rot away.
ai-sn35:241.2.2_0: Do not transmigrate the in the middle, nor by humans—a non-human being attached to people.
ai-sn35:241.2.3_0: In that case, you will slant, slope, and incline towards extinguishment.
ai-sn35:241.2.5_0: Because right view slants, slopes, and inclines towards extinguishment.”
ai-sn35:241.2.6_0: When this was said, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-sn35:241.2.7_0: “But sir, what’s the near shore and what’s the far shore? What’s sinking in the middle? What’s getting stranded on high ground? What’s getting taken by humans or non-humans? What’s getting caught up in a whirlpool? And what’s rotting away?”
ai-sn35:241.3.1_0: “‘The near shore’, mendicant, is a term for the six interior sense fields.
ai-sn35:241.3.2_0: ‘The far shore’ is a term for the six exterior sense fields.
ai-sn35:241.3.3_0: ‘Sinking in the middle’ is a term for greed and relishing.
ai-sn35:241.3.4_0: ‘Stranded on high ground’ is a term for the conceit ‘I am’.
ai-sn35:241.4.1_0: And what’s getting taken by humans?
ai-sn35:241.4.2_0: It’s when someone mixes closely with laypeople, sharing their joys and sorrows—happy when they’re happy and sad when they’re sad—and getting involved in their business.
ai-sn35:241.4.3_0: That’s called getting taken by humans.
ai-sn35:241.5.1_0: And what’s getting taken by non-humans?
ai-sn35:241.5.2_0: It’s when someone leads the spiritual life wishing to be reborn in one of the orders of gods:
ai-sn35:241.5.2_1: ‘By this precept by this precept or observance or mortification or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’
ai-sn35:241.5.3_0: That’s called getting taken by non-humans.
ai-sn35:241.5.4_0: ‘Caught up in a whirlpool’ is a term for the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
ai-sn35:241.6.2_0: It’s when some mendicant is unethical, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, corrupt, and depraved.
ai-sn35:241.7.1_0: Now at that time Nanda the cowherd was sitting not far from the Buddha.
ai-sn35:241.7.2_0: Then he said to the Buddha:
ai-sn35:241.7.3_0: “I won’t collide with the near shore or the far shore, or sink in the middle, or get stranded on high ground. And I won’t get taken by humans or non-humans or caught up in a whirlpool, and I won’t rot away.
ai-sn35:241.7.4_0: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
ai-sn35:241.7.5_0: “Well then, Nanda, return the cows to their owners.”
ai-sn35:241.7.6_0: “Sir, the cows will go back by themselves, since they love their calves.”
ai-sn35:241.7.7_0: “Still, Nanda, you should return them to their owners.”
ai-sn35:241.7.8_0: Then Nanda handed the cows took their backs and went to the Buddha.
ai-sn35:241.7.9_0: “Sir, I have returned the cows to their owners.
ai-sn35:241.7.10_0: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
ai-sn35:241.7.11_0: And the cowherd Nanda received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
ai-sn35:241.7.13_0: Venerable Nanda became one of the perfected.
ai-sn35:242.0.3_0: Right away the second tree trunk,
ai-sn35:242.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kimibilā on the bank of the Ganges river.
ai-sn35:242.1.4_0: “Mendicants, do you see that large tree trunk?”
ai-sn35:242.1.6_0: When this was said, Venerable Kimbila said to the Buddha:
ai-sn35:242.1.7_0: “But sir, what’s the near shore and what’s the far shore? What’s sinking in the middle? What’s getting stranded on high ground? What’s getting taken by humans or non-humans? What’s getting caught up in a whirlpool? And what’s rotting away?” ...
ai-sn35:242.1.9_0: It’s when a mendicant has committed the kind of corrupt offense from which there is no rehabilitation.
ai-sn35:243.1.1_0: At one time the Buddha was staying among the Sakyans near Kapilavatthu in Banyan Tree Monastery.
ai-sn35:243.1.2_0: Now at that time the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu had recently been sitting down. It had not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any person at all.
ai-sn35:243.1.3_0: and they went to the Buddha.
ai-sn35:243.1.3_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-sn35:243.1.3_2: and told him of their preparations, saying,
ai-sn35:243.1.4_0: “Sir, it’s when the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu have recently been constructed for nine or six days. It has not been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any person at all.
ai-sn35:243.1.5_0: May the Buddha be the first to use it,
ai-sn35:243.1.6_0: and only then will the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu use it.
ai-sn35:243.1.7_0: That would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.”
ai-sn35:243.1.8_0: And the Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-sn35:243.2.1_0: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, the Sakyans got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. Then they went to the new town hall, where they spread carpets all over.
ai-sn35:243.2.1_1: approached the Buddha, put out a seat, spread out water, and placed it in a pond. Then they went back to the Buddha, where they stood there.
ai-sn35:243.2.2_0: “The seats have been spread out, sir, and the seats spread out.
ai-sn35:243.2.4_0: Then the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the new town hall together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
ai-sn35:243.2.4_1: When he has washed his feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the central column facing east,
ai-sn35:243.2.5_0: The Saṅgha of mendicants also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the west wall facing east, with the Buddha right in front of them.
ai-sn35:243.2.6_0: The Sakyans of Kapilavatthu also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the east wall facing west, with the Buddha right in front of them.
ai-sn35:243.2.7_0: The Buddha spent most of the night educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the Sakyans with a Dhamma talk. Then he dismissed them, saying,
ai-sn35:243.2.10_0: “Yes, sir,” replied the Sakyans. They got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
ai-sn35:243.3.1_0: And then, soon after the Sakyans had left, the Buddha addressed Venerable Mahāmoggallāna,
ai-sn35:243.3.2_0: “Moggallāna, the Saṅgha of mendicants is rid of dullness and drowsiness.
ai-sn35:243.3.3_0: Give them some Dhamma talk as you feel inspired.
ai-sn35:243.3.7_0: And then the Buddha spread out his outer robe folded in four and laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
ai-sn35:243.3.8_0: There Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants,
ai-sn35:243.3.12_0: “I will teach you the explanation of the corrupt and the uncorrupted.
ai-sn35:243.3.13_0: listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn35:243.4.2_0: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with the eye. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart restricted.
ai-sn35:243.4.3_0: And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.

ai-sn35:243.4.5_0: know a thought with the mind. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and a limited heart.
ai-sn35:243.4.7_0: This is called a mendicant who is corrupt when it comes to sights known by the eye,
ai-sn35:243.4.10_0: When a mendicant lives like this, if Māra comes at them through the eye he finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
ai-sn35:243.4.11_0: If Māra comes at them through the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:243.4.12_0: If Māra comes at them through the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ... mind he finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.

ai-sn35:243.5.2_0: If a person came to it with a burning grass torch from the east,
ai-sn35:243.5.3_0: If a person came to the western quarter ...

ai-sn35:243.5.5_0: If they live in the south ...

ai-sn35:243.5.8_0: or from anywhere, the fire would find a vulnerability, it would get a foothold.
ai-sn35:243.5.9_0: In the same way, when a mendicant lives like this, if Māra comes at them through the eye he finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
ai-sn35:243.5.10_0: If Māra comes at them through the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:243.5.11_0: If Māra comes at them through the ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ... mind he finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
ai-sn35:243.5.12_0: When a mendicant lives like this, they’re mastered by sights,
ai-sn35:243.5.17_0: and thoughts, they don’t master these things.
ai-sn35:243.5.18_0: This is called a mendicant who has been mastered by sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and thoughts. They’re mastered, not a master. Bad, unskillful qualities have mastered them, which are defiled, leading to future lives, hurtful, and resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
ai-sn35:243.6.2_0: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with the eye. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
ai-sn35:243.6.3_0: And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.

ai-sn35:243.6.8_0: sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ... thoughts known by the mind.
ai-sn35:243.6.9_0: When a mendicant lives like this, if Māra comes at them through the eye he doesn’t find a vulnerability or get hold of them.

ai-sn35:243.6.11_0: mind he doesn’t find a vulnerability or get hold of them.

ai-sn35:243.7.2_0: If a person came to it with a burning grass torch from the east,

ai-sn35:243.8.1_0: Then the Buddha got up and said to Venerable Mahāmoggallāna:
ai-sn35:243.8.3_0: It’s good that you’ve taught this explanation of the corrupt and the uncorrupted.”
ai-sn35:243.9.1_0: This is what Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said,
ai-sn35:243.9.3_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said.
ai-sn35:244.1.1_0: “Mendicants, when a mendicant truly understands the origin and ending of all things that entail suffering,
ai-sn35:244.1.2_0: then they’ve seen sensual pleasures in such a way that they have no underlying tendency for desire, affection, infatuation, and passion for sensual pleasures.
ai-sn35:244.1.3_0: And they’ve awakened to a way of conduct and a way of living such that, when they live in that way, bad, unskillful qualities of desire and grief don’t overwhelm them.
ai-sn35:244.2.1_0: And how does a mendicant truly understand the origin and ending of all things that entail suffering?
ai-sn35:244.2.2_0: Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
ai-sn35:244.2.5_0: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.
ai-sn35:244.2.6_0: consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’
ai-sn35:244.2.7_0: That’s how a mendicant truly understands the origin and ending of all things that entail suffering.
ai-sn35:244.3.1_0: And how has a mendicant seen sensual pleasures?
ai-sn35:244.3.1_1: They’ve seen sensual pleasures in such a way that they have no underlying tendency for desire, affection, infatuation, and passion for sensual pleasures.
ai-sn35:244.3.2_0: Suppose there was a pit of glowing coals deeper than a man’s height, full of glowing coals that neither flamed nor smoked.
ai-sn35:244.3.2_1: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
ai-sn35:244.3.2_2: Then two strong men grab would grab each arm and drag them towards the pit of glowing coals.
ai-sn35:244.3.2_3: They’d writhe and struggle to and fro.
ai-sn35:244.3.4_0: For that person knows, ‘If I fall in that pit of glowing coals, that will result in my death or deadly pain.’
ai-sn35:244.3.5_0: In the same way, when a mendicant has seen sensual pleasures as like a pit of glowing coals, they have no underlying tendency for desire, affection, infatuation, and passion for sensual pleasures.
ai-sn35:244.4.1_0: And how has a mendicant awakened to a way of conduct and a way of living such that, when they live in that way, bad, unskillful qualities of desire and grief don’t overwhelm them?
ai-sn35:244.4.2_0: Suppose a person was to enter a thicket full of thorns.
ai-sn35:244.4.2_1: They’d have thorns in front and behind, to the left and right, below and above.
ai-sn35:244.4.2_2: So they’d go forward mindfully and come back mindfully, thinking:
ai-sn35:244.4.3_0: In the same way, whatever in the world seems nice and pleasant is called a thorn in the training of the Noble One.
ai-sn35:244.4.4_0: When they understand what a thorn is, they should understand restraint and lack of restraint.
ai-sn35:244.5.1_0: And how is restraint of restraint?
ai-sn35:244.5.2_0: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with the eye. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart restricted.
ai-sn35:244.5.3_0: And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
ai-sn35:244.5.4_0: tastes a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-sn35:244.5.5_0: know a thought with the mind. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and a limited heart.
ai-sn35:244.6.2_0: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with the eye. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
ai-sn35:244.6.3_0: And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
ai-sn35:244.6.4_0: tastes a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-sn35:244.6.5_0: know a thought with their mind. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
ai-sn35:244.6.6_0: And they do understand where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
ai-sn35:244.6.7_0: This is how there is restraint.
ai-sn35:244.7.1_0: Though that mendicant conducts themselves and lives in this way, every so often they might lose mindfulness, and bad, unskillful memories and thoughts prone to fetters arise.
ai-sn35:244.7.1_1: but they quickly give up, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts.
ai-sn35:244.8.1_0: Suppose there was an iron cauldron that had been heated all day, and a person let two or three drops of water fall onto it.
ai-sn35:244.8.1_1: The drops would be slow to fall, but they’d quickly dry up and evaporate.
ai-sn35:244.8.2_0: In the same way, though that mendicant conducts themselves and lives in this way, every so often they might lose mindfulness, and bad, unskillful memories and thoughts prone to fetters arise.
ai-sn35:244.8.2_1: but they quickly give up, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts.
ai-sn35:244.8.3_0: That’s how a mendicant has awakened for themselves and a awakened one.
ai-sn35:244.8.3_1: They’re living in such a way of desire and aversion, and bad, unskillful qualities of desire and aversion.
ai-sn35:244.8.4_0: While that mendicant conducts themselves in this way and lives in this way, it may be that rulers or their ministers, friends or colleagues, relatives or family would invite them to accept wealth, saying,
ai-sn35:244.8.5_0: ‘Come, good man, what let these ocher robes torment you?
ai-sn35:244.8.6_0: Why follow the practice of shaving your head?
ai-sn35:244.8.7_0: Come, return to a lesser life, enjoy wealth, and make merit!’
ai-sn35:244.8.8_0: It’s simply impossible for a mendicant who lives in this way to resign the training and return to a lesser life.
ai-sn35:244.9.1_0: Suppose that, although the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east,
ai-sn35:244.9.1_1: a large crowd were to come along with a spade and basket, saying:
ai-sn35:244.9.1_2: ‘We’ll make this Ganges river slant, slope, and incline to the west!’
ai-sn35:244.9.6_0: The Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.
ai-sn35:244.9.7_0: It’s not easy to make it slant, slope, and incline to the west.
ai-sn35:244.9.8_0: That large crowd will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
ai-sn35:244.9.9_0: “In the same way, while that mendicant conducts themselves in this way and lives in this way, it may be that rulers or their ministers, friends or colleagues, relatives or family should invite them to accept wealth, saying,
ai-sn35:244.9.10_0: ‘Come, good man, what let these ocher robes torment you?
ai-sn35:244.9.11_0: Why follow the practice of shaving your head?
ai-sn35:244.9.12_0: Come, return to a lesser life, enjoy wealth, and make merit!’
ai-sn35:244.9.13_0: It’s simply impossible for a mendicant who lives in this way to resign the training and return to a lesser life.
ai-sn35:244.9.15_0: Because for a long time that mendicant’s mind has slanted, sloped, and inclined to seclusion. So it’s impossible for them to return to a lesser life.”
ai-sn35:245.0.3_0: 245. The Simile of the Parrot Tree
ai-sn35:245.1.1_0: Then one mendicant went up to another mendicant and asked,
ai-sn35:245.1.2_0: “Reverend, at what point is a mendicant’s vision well purified?”
ai-sn35:245.1.3_0: “When a mendicant truly understands the origin and ending of the six sense fields, at that point their vision is well purified.”
ai-sn35:245.2.1_0: Not content with that answer, that mendicant went up to a series of other mendicants and received the following answers:
ai-sn35:245.2.1_1: He went to that monk and said to him,
ai-sn35:245.2.2_0: “Reverend, at what point is a mendicant’s vision well purified?”
ai-sn35:245.2.3_0: “When a mendicant truly understands the origin and ending of the five grasping aggregates, at that point their vision is well purified.”
ai-sn35:245.3.1_0: Not content with that answer, that mendicant went up to a series of other mendicants and received the following answers:
ai-sn35:245.3.1_1: He went to that monk and said to him,
ai-sn35:245.3.2_0: “Reverend, at what point is a mendicant’s vision well purified?”
ai-sn35:245.3.3_0: “When a mendicant truly understands the origin and ending of the four primary elements, at that point their vision is well purified.”
ai-sn35:245.4.1_0: Not content with that answer, that mendicant went up to a series of other mendicants and received the following answers:
ai-sn35:245.4.1_1: He went to that monk and said to him,
ai-sn35:245.4.2_0: “Reverend, at what point is a mendicant’s vision well purified?”
ai-sn35:245.4.3_0: “When a mendicant truly understands that everything that has a beginning has an end, at that point their vision is well purified.”
ai-sn35:245.5.1_0: Not content with any of those answers, that monk went to the Buddha.
ai-sn35:245.5.1_2: “Sir, where I approached one of the mendicants.
ai-sn35:245.5.1_3: He went to that monk and said to him,
ai-sn35:245.5.2_0: ‘Reverend, at what point is a mendicant’s vision well purified?’
ai-sn35:245.5.4_0: ‘When a mendicant truly understands the origin and ending of the six sense fields, at that point their vision is well purified.’
ai-sn35:245.5.5_0: Not content with any of these answers, I went to one of the mendicants.
ai-sn35:245.5.5_1: He went to that monk and said to him,
ai-sn35:245.5.6_0: ‘Reverend, at what point is a mendicant’s vision well purified?’
ai-sn35:245.5.8_0: ‘When a mendicant understands the five grasping aggregates ...
ai-sn35:245.5.9_0: truly understands the four primary elements, origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape ...”
ai-sn35:245.5.10_0: When a mendicant truly understands that all state is well purified, at that point their vision is well purified.’
ai-sn35:245.5.11_0: So I went up to the Buddha and received the answer of my answers with my answer.
ai-sn35:245.5.12_0: “Sir, at what point is a mendicant’s vision well purified?”
ai-sn35:245.6.1_0: “Mendicant, suppose a person had never seen a parrot tree.
ai-sn35:245.6.2_0: What’s what goes to a man and says?
ai-sn35:245.6.5_0: ‘A parrot tree is blackish, like a charred stump.’
ai-sn35:245.6.6_0: Now, at that time a parrot tree may well have been just as that person saw it.
ai-sn35:245.7.1_0: Not content with that answer, that person would go up to a series of other people and receive the following answers:
ai-sn35:245.7.4_0: ‘A parrot tree is blackish, like a charnel ground.’
ai-sn35:245.7.5_0: Now, at that time a parrot tree may well have been just as that person saw it.
ai-sn35:245.7.6_0: Not content with that answer, that person would go up to a series of other people and receive the following answers:
ai-sn35:245.7.9_0: ‘A parrot tree has flaking bark and burst pods, like an acacia.’
ai-sn35:245.7.10_0: Now, at each of those times a parrot tree may well have been just as those people saw them.
ai-sn35:245.7.11_0: Not content with that answer, that person would go up to a series of other people and receive the following answers:
ai-sn35:245.7.14_0: ‘A parrot tree has luxuriant, shady foliage, like a banyan.’
ai-sn35:245.7.15_0: Now, at each of those times a parrot tree may well have been just as those people saw them.
ai-sn35:245.7.16_0: In the same way, when they directly know and see any other good people, so long as they have learned them in line with the teachings,
ai-sn35:245.8.1_0: Suppose there was a king’s frontier citadel with fortified embankments, ramparts, and arches, and six gates.
ai-sn35:245.8.2_0: And it has a gatekeeper who is astute, competent, and clever. He keeps strangers out and lets known people in.
ai-sn35:245.8.3_0: A swift pair of messengers would arrive from the east and say to the gatekeeper,
ai-sn35:245.8.4_0: ‘Mister, where is the lord of the city?’
ai-sn35:245.8.6_0: ‘There he is, sirs, seated at the central square.’
ai-sn35:245.8.7_0: deliver a message of truth to the lord of the city and depart the way they came.
ai-sn35:245.8.8_0: A swift pair of messengers would come from the west ...
ai-sn35:245.8.10_0: A swift pair of messengers would arrive from the southern gate,
ai-sn35:245.8.11_0: ‘Mister, where is the lord of the city?’
ai-sn35:245.8.13_0: ‘There he is, sirs, seated at the central square.’
ai-sn35:245.8.14_0: deliver a message of truth to the lord of the city and depart the way they came.
ai-sn35:245.9.1_0: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
ai-sn35:245.9.3_0: ‘City’ is a term for this body made up of the four primary elements, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
ai-sn35:245.9.4_0: ‘Six gates’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.
ai-sn35:245.9.6_0: ‘A swift pair of messengers’ is a term for serenity and discernment.
ai-sn35:245.9.7_0: ‘The lord of the city’ is a term for consciousness.
ai-sn35:245.9.8_0: ‘The central square’ is a term for the four primary elements:
ai-sn35:245.9.10_0: ‘A message of truth’ is a term for extinguishment.
ai-sn35:245.9.11_0: ‘The way they came’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is,
ai-sn35:245.9.12_0: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.”
ai-sn35:246.1.1_0: “Mendicants, any monk or nun who has desire or greed or hate or delusion or repulsion come up for sights known by the eye should shield their mind from them:
ai-sn35:246.1.2_0: Even if they counsel, writing, and a thorn, they’re on the wrong path. And they are hard to get rid of the wrong path.
ai-sn35:246.1.3_0: If a bad person associates with bad people, and not frequented by it,
ai-sn35:246.1.5_0: The mind should be shielded from this when it comes to sights known by the eye.
ai-sn35:246.1.6_0: Any monk or nun who has desire or greed or hate or delusion or repulsion come up for sounds ... smells ... tastes ... touches ...
ai-sn35:246.1.7_0: thoughts known by the mind should shield their mind against them:
ai-sn35:246.1.8_0: Even if they counsel, writing, and a thorn, they’re on the wrong path. And they are hard to get rid of the wrong path.
ai-sn35:246.1.9_0: If a bad person associates with bad people, and not frequented by it,
ai-sn35:246.2.2_0: but the caretaker is negligent. If an ox fond of crops invades the crops they’d indulge themselves as much as they like.
ai-sn35:246.2.3_0: In the same way, when an uneducated ordinary person doesn’t exercise restraint when it comes to the six fields of contact, they indulge themselves in the five kinds of sensual stimulation as much as they like.
ai-sn35:246.3.1_0: Suppose the crops have ripened, and the caretaker is diligent. If an ox fond of crops invades the crops
ai-sn35:246.3.2_0: the caretaker would grab them firmly by the muzzle.
ai-sn35:246.3.3_0: Then they’d grab them above the hump and hold them fast there.
ai-sn35:246.3.4_0: Then they’d give them a good thrashing
ai-sn35:246.3.7_0: and even a third time, the same thing might happen.
ai-sn35:246.3.8_0: the caretaker would grab them firmly by the muzzle.
ai-sn35:246.3.9_0: Then they’d grab them above the hump and hold them fast there.
ai-sn35:246.3.10_0: Then they’d give them a good thrashing
ai-sn35:246.3.12_0: As a result, no matter how long they stand or sit in a village or wilderness, that ox fond of crops would never invade that crop again,
ai-sn35:246.3.13_0: remembering the beating they got earlier.
ai-sn35:246.3.14_0: In the same way, when a mendicant’s mind is stilled, it’s well settled, unified, and well immersed in samādhi it, but increases it.
ai-sn35:246.4.1_0: Suppose a king or their minister had never heard the sound of an arched harp.
ai-sn35:246.4.2_0: When he first hears the sound,
ai-sn35:246.4.4_0: ‘My man, what is making this sound, so arousing, sensuous, intoxicating, infatuating, and captivating?’
ai-sn35:246.4.8_0: ‘Go, my man, fetch me that arched harp.’
ai-sn35:246.4.13_0: ‘I’ve had enough of that arched harp! Just fetch me the sound.’
ai-sn35:246.4.15_0: ‘Sir, this arched harp is made of many components assembled together,
ai-sn35:246.4.16_0: which make a sound when they’re played. That is,
ai-sn35:246.4.17_0: it depends on the body, the skin, the neck, the head, the strings, the plectrum, and a person to play it properly. That’s how an arched harp is made of many components assembled together,
ai-sn35:246.4.18_0: which make a sound when they’re played.’
ai-sn35:246.4.19_0: But he’d split that harp into ten pieces or a hundred pieces, then splinter it up.
ai-sn35:246.4.20_0: He’d burn the splinters with fire, and reduce them to ashes.
ai-sn35:246.4.21_0: Then he’d sweep away the ashes in a strong wind, or float them away down a swift stream.
ai-sn35:246.4.23_0: ‘It seems that there’s nothing to this thing called an arched harp or whatever’s called an arched harp! But people waste their time with it, negligent and heedless!’
ai-sn35:246.4.24_0: In the same way, a mendicant searches for form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness anywhere they might be reborn.
ai-sn35:246.4.25_0: As they search in this way,
ai-sn35:246.4.28_0: consciousness extends as far as consciousness.
ai-sn35:246.4.29_0: their thoughts of ‘I’ or ‘mine’ or ‘I am’ are no more.”
ai-sn35:247.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose a person with wounded and festering limbs was to enter a thicket of thorny reeds.
ai-sn35:247.1.2_0: The kusa thorns would pierce their feet, and the reed leaves would scratch their limbs.
ai-sn35:247.1.3_0: And that would cause that person to experience even more pain and distress.
ai-sn35:247.1.4_0: In the same way, take a certain monk who goes to a village or wilderness. He thinks:
ai-sn35:247.1.5_0: ‘This venerable, acting like this, behaving like this, is a filthy village thorn.’
ai-sn35:247.1.6_0: Understanding that they’re a thorn, they should understand restraint and lack of restraint.
ai-sn35:247.2.1_0: And how is restraint of restraint?
ai-sn35:247.2.2_0: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with their eyes. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart restricted.
ai-sn35:247.2.4_0: When hearing a sound with the ear ...
ai-sn35:247.2.5_0: When smelling an odor with the nose ...
ai-sn35:247.2.6_0: Tasting a flavor with his tongue ...
ai-sn35:247.2.7_0: Feeling a touch with his body ...
ai-sn35:247.2.8_0: know a thought with the mind. If it’s pleasant they hold on to it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and a limited heart.
ai-sn35:247.3.1_0: Suppose a person holding a sunshade, with a strong rope around both shins, and tightly behind it.
ai-sn35:247.3.2_0: tie each up with a strong rope,
ai-sn35:247.3.3_0: and tie to a strong rope.
ai-sn35:247.3.4_0: tie each up with a strong rope,
ai-sn35:247.3.5_0: tie each up with a strong rope, then tie a strong rope.
ai-sn35:247.3.6_0: bound them with a strong rope,
ai-sn35:247.3.8_0: tie each up with a strong rope, then tie a knot in the middle and let them loose.
ai-sn35:247.3.9_0: Then those six animals with diverse domains and territories would each pull towards their own domain and territory.
ai-sn35:247.3.10_0: ‘I’ll reveal it that’s tradedy and drag it to you! I’ll reveal it!’ When placed it, I’ll roll it back to the beginning. I’ll pull it out.’
ai-sn35:247.3.11_0: When those six animals became exhausted and worn out, the strongest of them would get their way, and they’d all have to submit to their control.
ai-sn35:247.3.12_0: In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, their eye pulls towards pleasant sights, but is put off by unpleasant sights. Their ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:247.3.13_0: mind pulls towards pleasant thoughts, but is put off by unpleasant thoughts.
ai-sn35:247.4.2_0: Take a mendicant who sees a sight with the eye. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
ai-sn35:247.4.3_0: And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
ai-sn35:247.4.4_0: tastes a flavor with the tongue ...
ai-sn35:247.4.5_0: know a thought with their mind. If it’s pleasant they don’t hold on to it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
ai-sn35:247.4.6_0: And they do understand where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
ai-sn35:247.5.1_0: Suppose a person holding a sunshade, with a strong rope around both shins, and tightly behind it.
ai-sn35:247.5.2_0: tie each up with a strong rope,
ai-sn35:247.5.3_0: and tie to a strong rope.
ai-sn35:247.5.4_0: and he took hold of what was happening ...
ai-sn35:247.5.8_0: tie each up with a strong rope, then tether them to a strong post or pillar.
ai-sn35:247.5.9_0: Then those six animals with diverse domains and territories would each pull towards their own domain and territory.
ai-sn35:247.5.10_0: ‘I’ll reveal it that’s tradedy and drag it to you! I’ll reveal it!’ When placed it, I’ll roll it back to the beginning. I’ll pull it out.’
ai-sn35:247.5.11_0: When those six animals became exhausted and worn out, they’d stand or sit or lie down right by that post or pillar.
ai-sn35:247.5.12_0: In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, their eye doesn’t pull towards pleasant sights, and isn’t put off by unpleasant sights. Their ear ... nose ... tongue ... body ...
ai-sn35:247.5.13_0: mind doesn’t pull towards pleasant thoughts, and isn’t put off by unpleasant thoughts.
ai-sn35:247.5.14_0: This is how there is restraint.
ai-sn35:247.6.1_0: ‘A strong post or pillar’ is a term for mindfulness of the body.
ai-sn35:247.6.2_0: So, mendicants, you should train like this:
ai-sn35:247.6.3_0: ‘We will develop mindfulness of the body. We’ll cultivate it, make it our vehicle and our basis, keep it up, consolidate it, and properly implement it.’
ai-sn35:247.6.4_0: That’s how there is should be observance-day ceremonies.”
ai-sn35:248.1.1_0: “Mendicants, suppose a sheaf of barley was placed at a crossroads.
ai-sn35:248.1.2_0: Then six people would come along carrying flails,
ai-sn35:248.1.3_0: and started threshing the sheaf of barley.
ai-sn35:248.1.4_0: So that sheaf of barley would be thoroughly threshed by those six flails.
ai-sn35:248.1.5_0: Then a seventh person would come along carrying a flail,
ai-sn35:248.1.6_0: and they’d give the sheaf of barley a seventh threshing.
ai-sn35:248.1.7_0: So that sheaf of barley would be even more thoroughly threshed by that seventh flail.
ai-sn35:248.1.8_0: In the same way, an uneducated ordinary person is struck in the eye by both pleasant and unpleasant sights.
ai-sn35:248.1.9_0: When it comes to the tongue, the tastes ...
ai-sn35:248.1.10_0: mind by both pleasant and unpleasant thoughts.
ai-sn35:248.1.11_0: And if that uneducated ordinary person has intentions regarding rebirth into a new state of existence in the future, that foolish person is even more thoroughly struck, like that sheaf of barley threshed by the seventh person.
ai-sn35:248.2.1_0: Once upon a time, a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
ai-sn35:248.2.3_0: ‘My good sirs, if the demons defeat the gods in this battle, bind Sakka, the lord of gods, by his limbs and neck and bring him to my presence in the castle of demons.’
ai-sn35:248.2.4_0: There Sakka addressed the gods of the Thirty-Three:
ai-sn35:248.2.5_0: ‘My good sirs, if the gods defeat the demons in this battle, bind Vepacitti by his limbs and neck and bring him to my presence in the Sudhamma hall of the gods.’
ai-sn35:248.2.6_0: In that battle the gods won and the demons lost.
ai-sn35:248.2.7_0: So the gods of the Thirty-Three bound Vepacitti by his limbs and neck and brought him to Sakka’s presence in the Sudhamma hall of the gods.
ai-sn35:248.2.8_0: And there Vepacitti remained bound by his limbs and neck.
ai-sn35:248.2.10_0: ‘It’s the gods who are principled, while the demons are unprincipled. Now I belong right here in the castle of the gods.’
ai-sn35:248.2.11_0: Then he found himself freed from the bonds on his limbs and neck. He entertained himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation.
ai-sn35:248.2.13_0: ‘It’s the demons who are principled, while the gods are unprincipled. Now I will go over there to the castle of the demons,’
ai-sn35:248.2.14_0: he found himself bound by his limbs and neck, and the five kinds of heavenly sensual stimulation disappeared.
ai-sn35:248.2.15_0: That’s how subtly Vepacitti was bound.
ai-sn35:248.2.16_0: But the bonds of Māra are even more subtle than that.
ai-sn35:248.2.17_0: When you identify, you’re bound by Māra. Not identifying, you’re free from the Wicked One.
ai-sn35:248.3.1_0: These are all forms of identifying: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’
ai-sn35:248.3.2_0: Conceit is a disease, a boil, a dart.
ai-sn35:248.3.3_0: So mendicants, you should train yourselves like this: ‘We will live with a heart that does not identify.’
ai-sn35:248.4.1_0: These are all disturbances: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’
ai-sn35:248.4.2_0: Disturbances are a disease, a boil, a dart.
ai-sn35:248.4.3_0: So mendicants, you should train yourselves like this: ‘We will live with a heart free of disturbances.’
ai-sn35:248.5.1_0: These are all proliferations: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be emerging’, ‘I will be this’, ‘I will be endowed with all.’
ai-sn35:248.5.1_6: ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient’.
ai-sn35:248.5.2_0: Trembling is a disease, a boil, a dart.
ai-sn35:248.5.3_0: So mendicants, you should train yourselves like this: ‘We will live with a heart free of tremblings.’
ai-sn35:248.6.1_0: These are all proliferations: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be none of these things.’
ai-sn35:248.6.1_6: ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient’.
ai-sn35:248.6.2_0: Proliferation is a disease, a boil, a dart.
ai-sn35:248.6.3_0: So mendicants, you should train yourselves like this: ‘We will live with a heart free of proliferation.’
ai-sn35:248.7.1_0: These are all conceits: ‘I am’, ‘I am this’, ‘I will be’, ‘I will not be’, ‘I will have form’, ‘I will be formless’, ‘I will be percipient’, ‘I will be non-percipient’, ‘I will be neither percipient nor non-percipient.’
ai-sn35:248.7.2_0: Conceit is a disease, a boil, a dart.
ai-sn35:248.7.3_0: So mendicants, you should train yourselves like this: ‘We will live with a heart that has struck down conceit.’”
ai-sn35:248.7.4_0: ʻWe will do observance-day ceremonies that are legitimate and have a complete assembly.’”
ai-sn35:248.7.6_0: The fourth sub-chapter on entering is finished.
ai-sn35:248.8.3_0: Who is the chest of suffering?
ai-sn35:248.8.5_0: The fourth sub-chapter on those six sense fields is finished.
ai-sn35:248.9.1_0: The end of relishing and greed
ai-sn35:248.9.5_0: The Linked Discourses on the six sense fields are complete.
